title.narrative: COVID 19 Start Fund - Uganda

description.narrative: The Alert identified four impact domains of the COVID-19 crisis in northern Uganda: increased VAC and SGBV; increased MHPSS cases; higher risk of severe complications for elderly individuals; and PPE shortages at key health facilities. The approach proposed addressed three of the impacts. This consortium will leverage the collective strengths of our partners and address child protection and MHPSS concerns and manage procurement of PPE. The goal of the project is to help at-risk children, their caregivers and those who are struggling with psycho-social issues understand and navigate the systems and services available to them, while at the same time strengthening the capacity of the frontline staff in those systems. To address the issues of child protection and MHPSS, we propose to implement a multi-pronged mass media campaign targeting the general population with simple and effective messages by radio, while also supporting existing project volunteers/champions to spread the messages within their communities. In Karamoja where radio listenership is low, the project will use loudspeaker campaigns across the four targeted districts over 20 days. The mass media campaigns will include short messages across the three domains and a weekly series of five 1-hour sessions focused on parenting and stress management to support families. Where MOH, MGLSD and partners have already developed messages, the project will utilize these to deliver consistent messages aligned with government. For those messages that need be developed, a workshop with MOH and MGLSD will be held to ensure buy-in and ownership of the developed messages.

sector.narrative: Peacebuilding & Conflict resolution

title.narrative: Start Fund Zimbabwe Storm Chalane 2021

description.narrative:
This project will focus on 10,000 most vulnerable people or 2,000 Households (out of an estimated 100,000 people) that are expected to be in need of emergency wash assistance and protection support. These are selected as the anticipated priority interventions, based on the initial assessment work and key informant interviews World Vision has carried out. The activities are flexible, and World Vision could adjust the proposed interventions should the actual needs differ from those anticipated.
Chimanimani's District Civil Protection Unit and the associated Committees (DCPC) have set up 25 evacuation centers in Chimanimani. Sheltering is expected to last for at least 1-2 weeks, during which WASH and protection needs of the most vulnerable will be critical. The project will supply 60 handwashing stations to the evacuation centers in Chimanimani. These will be supplied with clean water for a period of 1-2 weeks, as long as it is required, inline with government estimates for how long the evacuation centres will be operational. Supplies of PPE (cloth facemasks and sanitisers) will be made available to the vulnerable groups inside evacuation centres, so that those most at-risk have reduced exposure to the spread of diseases, including COVID-19. Menstrual hygiene kits will be supplied to ensure that the dignity of women and girls during displacement is protected, as a key component of the project's protection strategy.
As it becomes increasingly safe for families to return to their homes, they can expect that water sources may be contaminated due to the anticipated levels of flooding in the district. The project will therefore focus on addressing these challenges by providing water purification aquatabs to 2,000 households - targeting child-headed households, under 5s and pregnant/lactation women, the elderly, people living with chronic illness, and people living with disabilities. The Civil Protection Committee has requested the provision of mosquito nets as they are severely lacking. These are important to protect people from maleria which is already high in the area.
In addition to the WASH needs of HHs evacuated and of those sheltering in place, the psychosocial support and protection will be needed in order to avoid deterioration of the well-being of young women and girls during the period where they are exposed to the shocks and most vulnerable. The project will seek to improve access to emergency GBV and child protection services both during displacement and during the early phase of communities returning to their homes, by working with Musasa, a nationwide provider of GBV services as well as Child Protection Society who provide child protection services at a grassroots level. Through support from the Start Fund project, these two organisations (among others) will work with World Vision to develop key messaging to support a public awareness protection campaign among households most affected by Tropical Storm Chalane in Chimanimani. Messaging will tackle the topics of child marriage, child exploitation and harmful child migration/labor which are rife in the region. World Vision , working with these protection expert organisations will carry out rapid protection assessments focusing on Evacuation Centers, displaced communities, and those communities within their original place of residents but who will have been severely affected. These rapid assessments will be used to refine key messaging. Awareness raising will be conducted through radio, mobile vans, and social media platforms. Through this campaign, the project will seek to increase the uptake of protection and GBV services at the time where the normal community-based protection structures are disrupted, and before events and decisions cause long-term harmful effects. As an adaptation to Covid-19, case management and psychosocial support will be provided through GBV emergency hotlines by service providers. The role of the project will be to make communities affected by Chalane aware of the services and encourage them to reach out for support during the disruption caused by the Tropical Storm.

sector.narrative: Water and sanitation

title.narrative: Start Fund Tropical Storm Chalane Mozambique

description.narrative:
On 30th December 2020, Severe Tropical Storm Chalane made landfall in Sofala Province, with strong winds of between 90 km/h and 130 km/h, accompanied by heavy rains of up to 100mm/24h. Chalane reached several districts in Sofala and Manica provinces, affecting over 9,200 families (more than 46,300 individuals), and resulting in the death of one individual and the injury of 13. Sofala and Manica Provinces were the worst affected by Tropical Cyclone Idai which impacted 1.8 million people in March 2019. As of November 2020, over 81,000 people who were displaced by Cyclone Idai were still living in resettlement sites. While attempting to recover from Idai and the impact of COVID-19 on their well-being and livelihoods, another shock in the form of Storm Chalane is testing the resilience of these populations. While the impact of the storm was not as severe as predicted (initial predictions were that it would be a cyclone), its effect on individuals who are still reeling from multiple shocks should not be understated. According to IOM, the shelters of 4,938 families living in Cyclone Idai resettlement sites in Sofala and Manica were completely or partially destroyed by Storm Chalane. This means that these populations have to rebuild for the second time in less than two years.
The proposed Start Fund Project is aiming to respond to Shelter, WASH and food needs while mainstreaming protection concerns.

sector.narrative: Water and sanitation

title.narrative: DEC COVID-19 Appeal Phase II - Preparedness for the COVID-19 epidemic in Idleb, North-west Syria

description.narrative: Phase II of the DEC COVID-19 Response is a continuation of Phase 1, which ends 31st January 2021. In summary, Phase II aims to continue supporting vulnerable communities and local health facilities to respond effectively to COVID-19 in Idleb (NW Syria) through the following: 1. Access to COVID-19 preventative supplies and adequate knowledge to prevent COVID-19 transmission 2. COVID-19 preventative messaging through Community Health Workers (CHWs) and social media 3. Continued support to health systems and facilities to have increased capacity for infection prevention and control (IPV) and treatment of suspected COVID-19 cases, particularly through Jisr As-Shugour hospital 4. Rehabilitation of sanitation facilities in health facilities.

sector.narrative: Health

title.narrative: Aid to support families and displaced individuals as a result of conflict in Cabo Delgado

description.narrative: Since late 2017, the northern province of Cabo Delgado in Mozambique has faced ongoing conflict with Islamic militant insurgency, often targeting civilians, with the intent of creating an Islamic state in the natural gas rich province. Access and humanitarian operations in the region has remained a challenge since this insurgency, with the humanitarian situation remaining acute, especially following the impact of Cyclone Kenneth April 2019, leaving 374,000 people in need, of whom an estimated 200,000 are still living in destroyed, damaged homes or makeshift shelters. Cabo Delgado remains the most vulnerable province in Mozambique with complex needs and ongoing security challenges. What has been of particular concern, however, is the surge of attacks that have been seen since March with some of the most severe attacks in May and beginning of June. The numbers of those forced to leave their homes from this conflict is growing as a result. Furthermore, existing humanitarian operations have been hampered with some temporarily halted. We targeted two districts (Montepuez and Chiure) which have experienced growing numbers of displaced people yet do not have resettlement centres or humanitarian aid distributions. This overcrowding and lack of provisions are especially concerning given that Cabo Delgado has the highest number of Covid-19 cases in the country and is currently experiencing a Cholera outbreak. Our response is aiming to reach approximately 3,000 households or 18,000 individuals with the following activities; 1. WASH needs for families, prioritising women and girls (ActionAid) 2. Awareness raising and prevention of Covid-19 (ActionAid & WJR/ADPP) 3. Distribution of essential Shelter items (ActionAid) 4. Prevention of GBV risks and protection concerns (ActionAid). 5. Immediate food needs (WJR/ADPP) 6. Medium-term food security and livelihoods (WJR/ADPP)

participating-org.narrative: Ajuda de Desenvolvimento de Povo para Povo (ADPP)

title.narrative: Helping schools in Manica and Sofala to prevent the spread of COVID-19

description.narrative:
In response to the initial spread of COVID-19, the Government of Mozambique closed both public and private schools on the 23rd of March 2020. This decision affected a total of 8.5 million children. Schools are currently scheduled to open in February 2021. While the initial disruption to children’s education has been significant, there is the possibility for further disruption if schools are unable to meet the COVID-19 safety standards prior to opening. If schools do not have adequate COVID-19 mitigation procedures and equipment in place they will be prevented from opening, thus potentially further disrupting children's education.
While the COVID-19 pandemic has presented difficulties and unique challenges to the entire population of Mozambique, communities that were still recovering from previous natural disasters have been especially affected by COVID-19. In particular, a number of communities in Sofala and Manica provinces were severely impacted by Cyclone Idai in 2019, a devastating cyclone that wreaked massive destruction and resulted in the sustained disruption for the region’s livelihoods and educational infrastructure (we responded to this at the time). Over a year after Cyclone Idai and at the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic, Sofala and Manica were still home to 20 of the most neglected resettlement sites and surrounding areas. In these areas, families were still struggling to rebuild, recover their livelihoods, and renew their children’s education. Inevitably, the COVID-19 crisis made an already difficult situation for displaced communities in Sofala and Manica even worse. The tertiary impacts of the pandemic, specifically the shutting down of schools which further disrupted children’s education and families’ livelihood opportunities, have been devastating and require immediate steps to be taken to prevent the situations from worsening. It is undoubtedly true that these secondary impacts of the COVID-19 crisis are felt throughout Mozambique, however, the impacts have been magnified in Sofala and Manica provinces where the communities were already struggling to recover economically and educationally in the aftermath of Cyclone Idai.
Project:
This proposed project and response will address two clear issues in Sofala and Manica provinces: the disruption of children’s education and the disruption of livelihoods for vulnerable families. Following assessments of needs and markets, we are proposing to target 1,600 households (8,000 individuals) to benefit by providing schools with the necessary items to properly and regularly sanitise classrooms, carry out sensitisation and awareness campaigns on COVID-19 prevention measures that involve for students and their families, installing water tanks and handwashing apparatuses at schools, and providing agricultural livelihood inputs for particularly in-need families. The project will target beneficiaries in Sofala and Manica provinces whose education and livelihoods were severely disrupted by Cyclone Idai and then further disrupted by the arrival of the COVID-19, compounding their already difficult circumstances. Special attention will be placed on ensuring that girls especially will be returning to schools after this disruption, as we know from previous epidemics that enrolment rates for girls dropped as increased rates of poverty, household responsibilities, child labour, early marriage and teenage pregnancy prevented many girls from returning to school.
The COVID-19 safety packs will contain the following for each school administration:
- 100 boxes of soap x 12
- 5 buckets with taps 100L each
- 4 sprayers for each school to disinfect the classroom -5 Two thermometers
Regarding livelihood support, this project will target the most vulnerable and in-need families of school-age children to provide with agricultural livelihood inputs, which predominantly includes women headed families. These inputs will allow families in need to begin to provide for their children a source of sustenance and potential income. The agricultural livelihood inputs will include mixed seeds (maize, beans, and vegetables) and hoes.
Lastly, due to the heightened risk of Gender Based Violence (GBV) and protection issues in the communities, we will involve the training of community activists on GBV issues, including a referral system to protect, defend and report cases in the target areas. In addition, at all distributions and activities, we will be distributing leaflets and conducting mass sensitisation campaigns highlight the risks of GBV, how to protect oneself, and how to report/respond to incidents.

participating-org.narrative: Ajuda de Desenvolvimento de Povo para Povo (ADPP)

title.narrative: Rwandan Answer to Pandemic through Investment and Development (RAPID)

description.narrative: 1) Vulnerable individuals in 4 sectors of Kayonza District (Mukarange, Gahini, Kabarondo, Nyamirama - these are 4 out 5 sectors in the district with any urban population): a) Older people’s households and individuals with comorbidities (300 households) According to the latest census (NISR, 2015), there are 2,863 individuals over 70 years old in these 4 sectors. Households with an older person seem uniformly to struggle with food scarcity. Support: information, hand-washing station, hygiene kit, food delivery over 6 months, follow-ups b) Informal workers’ households (425 households) The majority of 16,962 working age urban population of 4 sectors are working informally (domestic workers, market traders etc.). This group includes sex workers from Kayonza and Kabarondo towns who have been serving truck drivers delivering cargo between Kigali and Tanzania. Support: information, hygiene kit, cash transfers (month 1 – 425 households, month 2 – 300, month 3 – 200) c) Vulnerable families with children at-risk (250 households) SACCA has been already running a prevention programme for vulnerable families in the communities. Children in such families are at-risk of going to the streets because of carers’ inability to provide for the most basic needs. These are often households from Ubudehe 2 and they are not entitled for governmental support. Support: information, hygiene kit, cash transfers for 3 months, livelihoods support for 120 families over 3 months d) Girl street children (45) SACCA is one of 3 centres supporting street girls in Rwanda and the only one in the Eastern Province with a rehabilitation programme. SACCA has been contacted by the district transit centre for street children with a request to accommodate more girls. Support: rehabilitation in the centre, reintegration support 2) Patients of 15 health centres and 28 health posts (80,000 per month) in Kayonza district - the health facilities with be equipped with hand-washing stations and water tanks.

The project will strive to mitigate health as well as economic and social impacts of COVID‑19. It will adopt a youth-led approach. Given that the median age of the continent is 19.7 years, youth leadership will be critical for prevention and containment activities (World Economic Forum, 30/03/20). SACCA will build on its 5-years’ experience of training young people and extensive community links, and establish a community-based structure of 38 RAPID facilitators supported by 141 village communicators. Facilitators will be recruited from SACCA’s graduates who lost employment and other active youth. They will work closely with sector and cell leaders and identify “at-risk” groups to the virus and lockdown aftershocks (older people, people with disabilities, informal workers, vulnerable families etc.). The facilitators will support more than 5,000 households (at least 20,000 individuals) to adopt preventative behaviours to protect themselves and others from COVID‑19. They will train community members in hand-washing and deliver accurate messages as well as leaflets about the disease. The facilitators will be able to address the cultural and social factors around risk perception and risk management. They will ensure that their message does not increase stigma and does not deter people from reporting symptoms and seeking treatment. If facilitators come across cases that require psycho-social or other support, they will refer those to SACCA’s professional staff. Facilitators will distribute hygiene kits in line with WASH standards to 1,000 vulnerable households. These households will also receive masks made by a group of tailors with hearing impairments. They will also identify 300 the most at-risk individuals (elderly and those with comorbidities). The project will provide them with simple hand-washing station. The facilitators will promote a stay-at-home option while helping this group with food delivery in line with updated government’s guidelines (£21 per family of 4). We will also aim to support 675 vulnerable people who are the most affected by the aftermath of the lockdown (informal workers, families with large number of children etc.). In addition to information, during first 3 months, these households will be supported with cash transfers in line with government’s guidelines. During the following 3 months, when some informal workers will be able to restart paid work, the support will focus on 120 households to enable them to engage in subsistence agriculture. The facilitators will also signpost any available resources from the government or other organisations. The project will further complement the Government’s efforts to raise community awareness on COVID-19 and hygiene behaviours with a strong focus on the hard to reach population. It will also support 45 additional street girls in SACCA Rehabilitation Centre. It will also deliver essential hand-washing and other equipment to 15 health centres and 28 health posts in Kayonza District.

title.narrative: Livelihood and Food Security for Vulnerable People in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Rural communities in Sierra Leone face chronic poverty with inadequate incomes, food and nutrition, especially children, vulnerable mothers. 60% of the population are living on < $1.25/day (UNDP, DFID), in extreme poverty. 45% have insufficient year round food, 36% <5yrs suffer chronic malnutrition. Gender and disability discrimination, under/unemployment of youths exacerbate impoverishment. Through a proven sustainable CBO support model these vulnerable groups will be targeted in 15 communities (6000 households; >34,000 people) in Moyamba District to improve livelihoods and food security, through access to resources, markets, knowledge, skills on agriculture, enterprise; with integrated inputs on women’s/youths’ empowerment and wellbeing.

activity-date.narrative: The project works strengthening local CBOs (community based organisations) to enable them to provide services to their members, with 34,000 people in 6000 rural households as primary beneficiaries. The members of the CBOs come from the most disadvantaged and vulnerable groups in the community including 4400 Orphans and vulnerable children, 400 Girls married before age 18 and 1700 People with disabilities

description.narrative: COVID Rapid Response Disbursement to Overseas Partner

title.narrative: Increased food security and income among vulnerable farmers in Mvolo county, South Sudan

description.narrative:
60% of farmers reached will be women and 10% of farmers will be PWDs.
For the RRF project, 1,000 of 1,500 beneficiaries will be PLWDS. 500 of 1,500 beneficiaries will be single women, widows, lactating mothers or pregnant women.

The objectives of the project are: a) 2,000 rural farmers from will demonstrate improved agronomic practices to reduce their vulnerability by increasing productivity to support household food consumption and income generation. Given that education and literacy levels among adults in Mvolo (and in South Sudan generally) are particularly low, the agricultural training will be practical, hands-on and participatory to maximise comprehension, learning and impact. b) 66 farming groups with a minimum of 30 farmers in each will be formed across 66 villages, bringing together Jur, Dinka and IDPs who have settled in Mvolo to promote collaboration and reduce competition. c) 2,000 rural farmers will develop their basic literacy and numeracy skillsets as the project progresses and specific modules on FAAB, enterprise development and financial literacy will be delivered through FAL sessions delivered at community level. This will support farmers with transition from subsistence farming to income generation. d) 66 farming groups will also operate as VSLAs to increase financial security and further support improved livelihoods. Access to finance, which is currently absent in Mvolo, will support small scale business and enterprise development as well as increased household spending; both of which will contribute to improved quality of life at household level. e) The proposed project will utilise an integrated approach which combines livelihood development with peacebuilding; in recognition of the fact that, in this context, neither will succeed without the other. Peacebuilding activities will be integrated throughout to enhance social cohesion, mitigate the risk of conflict escalation and create an environment conducive to farming activities, income generation and ultimately development. 66 Peace Committees, established in each village, will bring together community leaders and stakeholders (male and female) as leaders in peace promotion. Increased community dialogue will contribute to increased understanding and tolerance amongst different stakeholder groups and increased community participation. Between October 2020 and March 2021, 15,000 marginalised and vulnerable households will receive emergency food relief and short-term duration crop kits to support them through the Covid-19 outbreak.

This project will support a transition from subsistence farming and aid dependency to sustainable livelihoods and development by building the capacity of 2000 farmers in 66 villages in Mvolo County, South Sudan. The project will promote peaceful coexistence among community stakeholders, including those from Jur and Dinka ethnic groups, as well as Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). Over the 36 month period, the project will increase food security in Mvolo, evidenced by an increase in crop production and income levels, improved access to finance through VSLAs, as well as a greater sense of security & cohesion at the community-level.
A sub-project has been funded by DFID in response to the outbreak of Covid-19. The project will deliver interim food relief to 1,500 marginalised and vulnerable households. The objective is the provision of emergency relief until restrictions on migrant workers are relieved, market prices decrease, and households can harvest again. The grant holder has designed a food package using Sphere standards, which will provide rations for a household of 6-9 people for up to eight weeks. As current relief agencies are struggling to bring WASH interventions to rural communities quickly, soap will also be provided for households. The project will provide short-term duration crop seeds, as well as socially distanced agricultural training on how to grow, care for and harvest them. These seeds will provide households with access to nutritious food relatively quickly. Literacy-sensitive learning cards will be developed for short-term duration crops, meaning households with low literacy levels can grow their crops without the need of a Field Officer. Simple foot-pedal water pumps will be supplied to clusters of households with particularly poor water access. Families will be selected based on a rapid needs assessment and in collaboration with traditional leaders, local government, and other agencies. Emergency food relief will be distributed at an accessible point, adhering to social distancing requirements. Alongside these physical interventions, the grant holder will conduct house-to-house awareness raising activities to ensure beneficiaries are prepared and mobilised in way of signs and symptoms, transmission prevention and healthcare provision.

title.narrative: Raising Aspirations: Disabled Youth Make the Sustainable Development Goals a Reality in Rwanda.

description.narrative: Impact: Children and young people with disabilities are fully included in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development in Rwanda. Outcome: 80 youth and children with disabilities in Rwanda have improved capability and a more enabling environment to hold their government to account for disability inclusion and SDG implementation in Rwanda. Output 1: 80 youth with disabilities have increased skills and knowledge to influence change and counsel others on disability rights. Output 2: Government create a more enabling environment through which youth with disabilities can hold decision makers to account in the prioritisation of disability in SDG implementation. Output 3: Community members in 5 target districts have greater understanding and awareness of disability rights and inclusion and are better able to hold government to account for stated commitments. Output 4: Improved capacity of our partner organisation (UWEZO) to create and utilise a strong evidence base of best practice inclusive approaches and influence government to deliver stated commitments to disability inclusion in the SDGs.

Information about additional COVID-19 Rapid Response project (same activity ID) delivered 1st October 2020 to 28th February (“I Matter Too: Ensuring Rwandan children with disabilities are clean, happy and safe during COVID-19”):
Responding to the COVID-19 pandemic, this project takes a holistic approach to strategically address the immediate inequalities faced by children with disabilities in Rwanda at this time. Activities will ensure 135 of the most vulnerable children with disabilities are clean, happy and safe during the COVID-19 crisis. The project will ensure children with disabilities are clean through the provision of inclusive WASH mentorship, information and hygiene supplies; it will ensure children with disabilities are happy through specialised psychosocial consideration including mental health and wellbeing mentorship, with the provision of professional psychological support for those identified as most severe. Finally, children with disabilities will be kept safe during the pandemic through the promotional of rights-based materials, and the creation of a safeguarding helpdesk which will allow incidents of harm or abuse against children with disabilities to be reported and actioned. The project aims to respond meaningfully to the gaps identified in the current COVID-19 response when considering children with disabilities.

This project contributes to the SDGs aspiration to ‘leave no one behind’ in Rwanda by empowering children and young people with disabilities to demand inclusion in the SDGs. This project uses a tested and new youthled model whereby young PWDs are trained to mentor CWDs and are the main drivers for inclusion at a community and government level. The project aims to find youth-led solutions for meaningful inclusion and creates mechanisms whereby disabled youth can communicate evidence of best practice to policy makers. The project has been developed jointly with UWEZO Youth Empowerment, a youth led DPO in Rwanda, and AbleChildAfrica. The inspiration for the project was learning from a baseline completed by UWEZO in 2014 and outcomes of a 2 year pilot project.

sector.narrative: Youth empowerment for disability inclusive SDG implementation

title.narrative: Somalia: DEC Coronavirus Appeal Phase 2

description.narrative:
Apart from the other layers of hazards existing in the target areas, COVID-19 had also impacted small scale farmers. It has been reported many farmers have abandoned their farming and sought an alternative source of income from the nearby towns. This has increased and exposed the farmers to the risk of COVID 19. A. Food security of poor farmers through revitalizing agricultural production in the targeted areas. Through cash for work, irrigation canal will be rehabilitated, and farm inputs will be supplied. The rehabilitation work will be on excavating (desilting) of flood damaged canals. This will improve the accessibility and availability of water for irrigation uses. Two canals with dimension of 2m width and 1m depth and 2km length will be rehabilitated. Each canal will provide water to 10 farms. In addition to this, the farmers will receive an improved seed such as maize, sesame, tomatoes and pumpkins. Availing water and seeds to farmers will improve their farm activities and reduce the risk of seeking labour to unsafe environments. In doing this the farmers will start producing by themselves and subsequently able to both feed their families and sell their produce. The project will link to farmers to the existing potential markets through establishing a network between agriculture traders and target farmer groups. This activity will be done for 15 days by 200 farmers at a rate of $5 per day. Each farm will be distributed with farm equipment’s worth $200
B. Increased employment opportunity through VSLA and income generating activities: As COVID 19 had mostly impacted poor and vulnerable people who were dependent on market activities such as labour, aid and family support. In the first phase, the project had transferred cash to maintain the minimum food basket for target households. The cash had supported families to sustain their livelihoods in specific periods of the project. In order to move to an early socio-economic recovery, on the second phase, the project intends to transition from short term cash transfer to more sustainable income generating activities. The project will introduce a village, saving and loans association approach (VSLA) to improve access to financial resources for poor households, targeting women in priority. The primary purpose of a VSLA is to provide simple savings and loan facilities and through these and other enabling activities empower women to manage resources and invest them for the benefit of their household. Loans can provide a form of self- insurance to members, supplemented by a saving fund which provides small but important income to members in distress. The VSLA system enables members of a self-selected group to voluntarily save money through purchasing shares. The savings are then invested in a loan fund from which members can borrow as well as meet their immediate needs such as food, water and health care or make further investments to diversify and increase their incomes. The project will support 15 VSLA groups of 15 – 20 members with initial seed fund of 3000 USD for each group. The activity will start with community mobilization, selection of households to participate and group formation. While the methodology is simple, it depends on a very carefully structured system of training. Over seven sessions, groups learn to: form their associations; define a purpose; elect officials; design their system of savings, insurance and credit; and practice running savings and credit meetings. Once this process is completed, VSLAs can begin to save and to lend. They are supervised over a period of 12 months by field staffs who ensure procedures and systems work properly and that the groups can function independently thereafter;
C. Health: Strengthened capacity of existing health facilities and services to combat Covid-19. The proposed project will provide 18 PPE kits to 3 health facilities in the seven IDP camps and the three designated COVID 19 referral hospitals. The proposed project will equip 11 COVID 19 screening centres in the to do surveillance and early detection at the primary health care centres in the IDP camps, provide cleaning and sterilising equipment and supplies to these facilities to limit hospital infections. Other activities also include procurement of medicines, community mobilization outreach and training of frontline health workers. IR will also work with the government hospitals and other unit of covid-19 task force in the preparation of covid roll-out. IR will support through advocacy and media outreach for people to accept and take the vaccines. This approach of advocacy, lobbying through media and electronic information sharing will enable the roll-out of vaccines. IR will also use its health facilities as centre for passing information to patients and their dependents to take up vaccines once its made available. Similarly, IR will by making available a vehicle and a driver support the ministry of health with logistics mainly in Balaad, Baidoa and Bandar districts.
D. WASH: The project will expand water points in IDPs. In some IPDs for instance Dayniile district, the accessibility of water stands for handwashing is still very small. The water point will allow beneficiaries to easily access water points for handwashing in their proximity. The expansion will include laying out of pipes and construction of fenced water points. The expansion will improve the sanitation and hygiene of IDP communities so that they can prevent from themselves the spread of COVID 19 pandemic. The water points will be placed in strategic position such as schools and health centres. Additionally, IR will construct water tanks, piping system, training of water committee with a view to make water available for covid-19 prevention.
E. Protection: Since there is a prevailing reports of incidence of gender based violence, early marriage, the project will carry out an awareness sessions including training of women and men. These sessions will be in line with Islamic Relief Somalia safeguarding and protection principles.

title.narrative: Remote Capacity Building of Iraqi, Syrian and Yemeni NGOs to Adapt to COVID-19 Context

description.narrative:
The core of the project is provision of remote mentoring and coaching, based on the capacity building needs assessment of respective NGOs. The mentoring and coaching is based on the existing online resources for organizational strengthening/ adjustment to COVID-19 as well as COVID-19 response.
HAD will provide urgent capacity development to frontline local NGOs in Iraq, Syria and Yemen. The project is planned to be implemented over the course of 3 months.
The project is to enable the frontline NGOs to (i) adapt to COVID-19 and carry on with their programmes, (ii) implement COVID-19 interventions with the local populations. To this extent, all project activities focus on strengthening NGOs capacities.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Response in Somalia

description.narrative: The key objective is to implement preventative measures for vulnerable groups that have limited access to COVID-19 prevention and response actions. This is to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 in urban IDP settings. The intervention will focus on the most vulnerable groups: older people – forming approximately 2.7 per cent of the population and the urban poor and IDPs about 75% of the population. Assessments shows these as most vulnerable who are heavily impacted by COVID-19 infection. For this response, IRS seeks to complement the efforts of the government and other humanitarian organisation in Somalia by reaching approximately 40,000 beneficiaries directly and up to 200,000 indirectly. 1. Risk communication and community engagement. The proposed project will support preventative measures to combat the spread of COVID 19. This will include extensive awareness initiatives using multiple media channels to support preventative action of the government and communities. The information/ education and communication is designed to reach the population through print, audio-visual media messages, SMS and community mobilisation using religious/community/group leaders and elders. Display monitors on COVID 19 risks and prevention in local language will be installed at strategic locations such as roundabouts, airports and community centres in IDP camps. 2. Health: Strengthen existing health facilities in the selected IDP camps to combat COVID 19 infection. The proposed project will provide 18 PPE kits to seven health facilities in the seven IDP camps and the three designated COVID 19 referral hospitals. The proposed project will also set up and equip 11 COVID 19 screening centres in the to do surveillance and early detection at the primary health care centres in the IDP camps, provide cleaning and sterilising equipment and supplies to these facilities to limit hospital infections. 3. WASH: Reduce the spread of COVID 19 and decrease morbidity and mortality in the selected districts. The project improve hygiene practices, limiting infection IDP camps.24 hand-washing stations will be built in the IDP camps in Bondhere, Baidoa, Balcad, Gardho and Burtinle. Hygiene kits, containing bath soap, laundry soap, 2 jerry cans, and facemask, will be supplied to 3500 households. Special consideration will be given to female headed household and PWD. 4. Livelihood: Improving livelihoods through unconditional cash transfer of USD 70 for 3 months to 333 households, and USD 70 cash assistance for 2 months to 333 households as livelihoods support. The beneficiaries will be selected using robust selection criteria that targets the most vulnerable and prioritise female headed household. The UCT will be done using mobile money transfer which has the benefit of increased security, convenience, privacy, speed, reduced operational/transaction costs and logistics for the beneficiaries and for Islamic relief. Somalia has large mobile network reach. The choice of money gives the beneficiaries the widest range of transactional capabilities and broad access to basic financial services (such as deposit, withdrawal, person-to-person transfers and e-money transactions with registered traders of goods and service providers). Islamic Relief used mobile money in drought/ flood emergency programme (including WFP Baxnaano programme). The lessons from previous experience which guide the choice of UCT include: - Beneficiaries purchase a more diverse set of goods, had higher dietary diversity, - Beneficiaries depleted fewer assets and grew more types of crops, especially marginal cash crops grown by women. They are able to o restock livelihood assets faster. The reasons for this can be attributed to the lower costs and greater privacy of receiving a cash transfer via the mobile transfer, as well as changes in intra-household decision-making. 5. Establish complaint management and feedback mechanism to the affected population. Through this intervention, IR MEAL unit will ensure that project delivers responses as designed to the affected population. Through an established mechanism of complaints mechanism and feedback channels, the affected population will be made to understand and demand their rights until all is provided to their satisfaction. 6. Build and establish DRR community champions for covid-19 preparedness, response and treatment. The established committee is trained on covid-19 risk reduction management. Their role is to ensure that community members are made aware of the impact of covid-19, where to seek treatment and how to enforce containment measures such as social distancing and use of mask and sanitisers as part of exposure reduction. IRS will lead the implementation. The project will build on existing IRS interventions in health WASH and livelihood sectors and maximise the impact and sustainability

title.narrative: Africa Investment Technical Assistance Facility

description.narrative: The UK-Africa Investment Summit aimed to drive increased investment into Africa and long-term inclusive growth. The UK Government established a Technical Assistance (TA) Facility to support the preparation and delivery of Summit content. It provided analysis, digital content and factsheets, as well as support to the delivery of a series of pre-Summit events. The UK-Africa Investment Summit TA Facility was led by PwC and drew on expertise from an alliance that included WAVTEQ, Vivid Economics, OCO Global, WG Inclusive and Adam Smith International. The contract is being extended to build on the legacy of the Summit to monitor impact, deliver scoping studies and technical advice around trade and investment in Africa, particularly related to Covid-19. The alliance remains the same, with the addition of Wellspring Development Capital.

title.narrative: AmplifyChange Fund Projects Implemented in South Africa

description.narrative:
This IATI activity file represents the grantees receiving AmplifyChange funding for their projects in South Africa. Certain projects may have been anonymised in the data for safety and security reasons. AmplifyChange is a multi-donor fund that supports civil society organisations who advocate for improved sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR). AmplifyChange offers both financial and capacity-building support to selected civil society organisations through a challenge fund model, where organisations submit applications in competitive funding rounds. AmplifyChange is managed by MannionDaniels in consortium with the African Women’s Development Fund and Global Fund for Women.
AmplifyChange was tendered in 2013, established in 2014, and the first funding rounds were held in 2015. The number of donors have increased since the beginning to a current total pot of approximately £90 million available for grant making (correct as of end-2017); the additional donor commitments have been extended to 2021. The donors include the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Denmark (Danida), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, ViiV Healthcare, the Department of International Development (DFID) the Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (Norad), Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (SIDA) working with the Swedish Association for Sexuality Education (RFSU), and one anonymous donor. Please refer to the parent IATI activity of this country activity for more information on the Fund.
AmplifyChange Fund support civil society organisations (CSOs) primarily in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, with some small grants being extended to organisations operating in Latin America, the Middle East and East Asia. Applicants can apply across four grant types: 1) Opportunity Grants: maximum 10,000 Euros over 1-year maximum 2) Strengthening Grants: between 40,000 – 100,000 Euros over 6 to 24 months 3) Network Grants: between 150,000 – 550,000 Euros over 2 years 4) Strategic Grants: between 550,000 to 2 million Euros over 2 years.

title.narrative: Enhance the capacity of Female Police in Yemen: Mainstreaming a gender-based approach within the law enforcement

description.narrative:
Introduction Nov. 2018 - October 2019: On November 2018, a contract (reference No. AVT16/BZ120646A) was signed between the state of the Netherlands, represented by HE the Minister for Foreign Trade and Development, legally represented by HE the Ambassador to Yemen and Penal Reform International. To implement a project titled “Enhance the capacity of Female Police in Yemen: Mainstreaming a gender-based approach within the law enforcement”. The project overall goal is to Enhance peace and security efforts in Yemen through building the capacity of the female police unit at the MoI. Through achieving the following outcomes. 1) 700 female police officers in the female police unit are better able to maintain law and order according to human rights standards and rules of administration of justice. 2) A gender sensitive approach in the work of MoI is mainstreamed through improved safeguards for female police officers. 3) Barriers to women reporting crimes are removed. 4) Improved international standards and best practice in ensuring equal opportunities for women in the police force. The target groups of this project are MoI, 700 female police officers that were hired in the South, the Police Academy. While the final beneficiaries of the project are: society at large in Yemen, with a focus on vulnerable groups including women, children, marginlised groups. To achieve the overall goal and the specific results of the project, PRI worked closely with relevant governmental stakeholders including (MoI, female police unit under the family protection department at MoI). “ MoI- PRI MoU governing the project implementation” PRI has a strong partnership with the MoI and our contact person for the project from MoI side is the Deputy Minister, colonel Ali Al-Aksha, who provides full support to the project content and activities. This working relation was governed by the project theory of change outlined below in Figure No.1. which illustrates how the sequence of events, activities and interventions taken within the course of the project, are expected to contribute achieving the project goal. The theory of change is reviewed regularly in light of the political changes and local context with the aim of reviewing its validity and viability to reach the project outcomes. Up till the end of the first year, it still valid and achievable despite political challenges. The report will be divided into two sections, section I Project Problem Statements and Political Overview, and Section II Achievements of Project Results and Activities. Section I: Problem Statement and Political Overview: This section will include a brief account of the political situation in Yemen; it shows the degree to which those political conditions have affected the project implementation. Since the war started in 2015, the political and security situation in Yemen continued to be a major challenge for the criminal justice system. The ongoing instability in Aden and the southern governorates, and the clashes led by different groups including Al-Qaeda, and the Southern separation council against the official government, caused a challenge and slowed the implementation of the project activities. But despite that, the MoI continued to express the full political support for the project and its objectives, and the determination to deploy female police to serve in several locations with the aim of facilitating justice access and enhancing the access of females to the police and the justice system. A closer scene of the political situation in Yemen during the current reporting period showed a very volatile and unpredictable situation due to the on-going active armed conflict in the country. During this period, political campaigns were seeking to resolve the internal conflict which lasted for the past five years. Those political campaigns have created tensions which eventually turned into intermittent armed clashes, long and short-term interference, moreover leading to creation of active frontlines. PRI interventions were designed to target the Southern region, which over the past months has remained a point of focus, most of its governorates were relatively calm, but very uncertain due to the various spread of armed actors representing various political angles with different agendas. Although the numbers of incidents have gradually decreased, acts of terrorism remain very high, and the threat is still assessed as extreme due to the presence of Al-Qaeda in Arabic Peninsula and IS operatives. Other threats related to the on-going armed conflict continue to hinder a lot of operations in the south region and the country as a whole. Politically, both the International Recognized Government (IRG)and Southern Transitional Council (STC) made progress during the period by signing a Southern Peace Agreement (commonly referred as Riyadh Agreement). The agreement was set on the 5th of November 2019, where both parties – IRG and STC agreed on the framework, therefore to end the tensions between the two actors. On the onset of the agreement, both stakeholders formed integrated committees to release the control on military camps and other government facilities that are currently under the Southern Transitional Council (STC) control. Despite the formation of the committee’s members from both parties, the implementation of this agreement is very slow, and nothing significant has taken place on the ground, despite the committee presence and both parties’ commitment. This has a direct impact on one component of the project, that is related to the location of the female police Academy. Since the building that was chosen by the MoI to be the location of the academy still under the control of the STC, and not yet handed to the Ministry of interior , which resulted in slowing the process of establishing the physical logistical building of the Academy. PRI was informed by the MoI to wait till April 2020 to solve this issue. Otherwise, a new building that is in Hadhramaut might be chosen. However, we do prefer to keep the location in Aden, for the academy to be closer to the MoI, taking into consideration that the majority of recruited female officers are in Aden, the temporary capital. Which on the long term will have an impact on making the decision for joining the police force easier for women who for social reasons prefer not to travel between governorates alone. In conclusion, the tensions continue to hinder a lot of operations in the country; due to the bureaucratic impediments from various actors. The absence of the International Recognized Government (IRG) in the South – and particularly in Aden Governorate which serves as the interim capital city of IRG, has led to the closure of several Ministries including the Ministry of Interior. During the current reporting period, a positive and negative effect were noticed in the key two institutions in the current project represented by the Ministry of Interior-(MoI) and the Women Police as follows:  Ministry of Interior Situation: Tense security situation, which increased in August 2019, between the International Recognized Government (IRG) and the southern Transitional Council (STC) has led to the closure of several line Ministries including the Ministry of Interior. On the 5th of November 2019, both Government (IRG)and Southern Transitional Council (STC) made progress by signing Southern Peace Agreement (commonly referred as Riyadh Agreement) therefore to end the tensions between the two actors. Integrated committee formed to oversee the handing over of the military camps and other government facilities that are currently under the control of Southern Transitional Council (STC). This committee faced challenges to make progress on the ground. The above situation and the absence of the Ministry of Interior decision-makers which led to slower coordination mechanisms with the government and caused delay in some activities’ implementation like Female Police Academy rehabilitation work.  Female Police Situation in Yemen: After signing Riyadh Agreement, life started back normally on the ground, and Female Police started going back to their workplaces where they are employed like the airport, migration offices, Prisons, coastguard … Before the war and according to official records of the MoI before 2015, Women constituted 1.7 % of police forces, with the total number of 2868 female officers. Women started joining the police forces in 2001 after graduation from the Police Academy in Yemen. When the first group of officers graduated, they were sent to serve at all locations, similar to their male colleagues. However, as Yemen is a very conservative society and security forces are controlled by male attitudes, policewomen faced several levels of harassment and discrimination that led many of them to leave the service and stay at home. Consequently, the figures above do not reflect the real representation of women within the police force. In 2017 the numbers of female police in Aden increased to 300 female police officers. Another registration happened during 2018 were the 700 female police officers has been registered so the total number now is 1000 female police. Those females are working now in Aden in Several government places , female police working in 23 police station in all Aden districts, in , Migration Directorate, Prison Directorate, coastguard and Airport. Challenges faced by policewomen in Yemen: Female police officers in Yemen face many challenges that are rooted in prejudice regarding distinctions between genders. Gender discrimination and harassment (sexual and verbal) of female police officers along with continued displays of negative attitudes by male police officers led to many women leaving the police forces. In addition to male negative attitudes, female police officers still face “barriers” that hinder their career advancement opportunities within the organization. These include discriminatory policies, a management that does not believe in their role, barriers to their career development path, and equipment and facilities’ inadequacies--including material conditions at work – for example, locker rooms, changing facilities, lavatories . . . Additionally, policewomen face a number of other social problems that are inherent in the larger society. These include family responsibilities, role strain and role conflict, doubts about competence and self-worth, sexual harassment, and a concomitant fear of complaining about abuse. The current project is working in partnership with MoI senior management to eliminate and reduce the effect of these challenges. The first step in achieving this was done during the first six months, through creating a structure within MOI ( female Police Unit) that is assigned the task of managing this force based on international standards, and with a clear framework that sets out their duties; including the development of terms of reference (TORs) that clarify their work at various levels and locations. With the aim of creating an encouraging working environment for the 700 newly hired women police officers, enabling them to deliver their work effectively, and with dignity and pride. It is expected that the added value of the Female police unit will be, promoting gender equality within police forces, enabling women’s access to justice / protecting women’s rights during conflict and post conflict periods and effective response to Gender based Violence.

The ongoing instability in Aden and the southern governorates, and the clashes led by different groups including Al-Qadeh, and the Southern separation council against the official government. Caused a challenge and slow down the implementation of the project activities. But despite that the MOI continued to express their full political support for the project and its objective and their determination to deploy female police to serve in several location with aim of facilitating justice and enhancing the access of females to the police and the justice system.
A closer scene of the political situation in Yemen during the current reporting period showed a very volatile and unpredictable situation due to the active armed conflict and clashes between the international recognized government (IRG) and the transitional council (TC) The clashes have started on March 2020 and continued till Ramadan holy month. On the same period, natural disasters have encountered the country, heavy rains and flooding which started in mid-April continued across the country. Flooding has damaged roads, bridges and the electricity grid, and contaminated water supplies, cutting access to basic services for thousands of people. In Sana’a, flooding caused widespread disruption to services as the city was overwhelmed by floodwaters. In Aden, power cuts have continued since the floods of 21 April. There is heightened risk of diseases such as malaria and cholera.
Similar to other countries around the world, Yemen has been suffering from the impact of COVID-19 during the reporting period yet with a magnified effect or impact, due to the effect of the war on the Yemeni health system, as since five years of war has shattered the country's health system, leaving it incapable of coping with a pandemic. Many of Yemen's medical facilities have been damaged or destroyed in air strikes, and only half are thought to be fully functioning. Clinics are reported to be crowded, and basic medicines and equipment are lacking - in a country of 27.5 million people there are only a few hundred ventilator machines. COVID has also an impact on slowing down the work, were the work on renovating the police academy had to stop due to the pandemic and the lockdown forced by the authorities, training workshops had to be suspended till the lockdown is left.
Challenges faced by policewomen in Yemen: Per PRI’s Interviews with the female police officers enrolled in the PRI capacity building interventions that took place during the first year of the project, the female officers have expressed that they have experienced many setbacks because of the lack of training due to the lack of resources given to them, and as Yemen is a conservative society, they didn’t give much attention, or chances to the fact that woman police needed continuous training, the need to expand their resources through enrolment and through on ground practical training, and theoretical knowledge which would help them to increase their expertise and increase their ranks to be leaders in the police forces . The need for the police academy to be built and maintained at high expectations is a need to compensate for the lack of experience and knowledge that the women police force needed. Some Officers felt left out long time ago, and felt that they were not given the equal right of men to perform their tasks, and duties, yet they remain excited, and eager to earn knowledge, and gain experience to enable them to perform at their highest capabilities in order to serve their country, and their cause. The trainings organized by PRI as part of this project did give them a good head start, but the continues need for extra knowledge and training skills is still an obstacle due to the lack of resources.
Theory of change The project theory of change was affected by the political, natural disinters and the impact of COVID-19, and some changes needs were introduced at the outcomes level to response to that. The original plan was that the project target the all of the 700 police officers, however, due to the delays in finalizing the academy that was impacted by the ongoing conflict and the division at the government level in Aden, the floods and the COVID-19. All of the 700 officers will not be able to benefit from the training before the end of the project, it is expected that the project will be able to target around 400 officers, only at this phase. While the training of the rest of the officers can be resumed during 2021. However, it should be mentioned that due to the difficult financial situation that the government in Aden is facing, more financial support will be needed till the academy is able to function smoothly and based on annual plan. The logic behind the theory of change is still valid and follow the logic and the project approach that was chosen when the project started. It worth to mention that the project team have a process of continuous revision of the theory of change and the risks on the ground and acted on adopting mitigating factors that aimed at reducing these risks to be able to achieve the results of the project and its outcomes. However, the political situation and all the delays were beyond PRI control.

Overall Goal and Achievements of Project Results and Activities Nov. 2018 - October 2019: The project aims at achieving the following goal: enhance peace and security efforts in Yemen through building the capacity of the female police unit at the MOI. During the reporting period this goal was the major message that was used to promote the establishment of the Women police unit and the academy. In all the correspondence with the Yemeni authorities, PRI stressed on the importance that the female police will play a major role in terms of securing peace and security in Yemen. A goal that was welcomed by the Yemeni MOI who confirmed their willingness to work towards achieving the project goal. The indicators for this goal by their nature can’t be assessed at this stage of the project life, measuring these indicators will be only possible once the female officers are deployed to their duty stations. Goal indictor NO.1: Percentage of the public reporting feeling safer since the introduction of the female police unit Goal indictor NO.2: Percentage of the public who are satisfied with the work of the female police unit and its contribution towards peace and security efforts. II.II Project outcomes: While the outcomes identified by the project, are considered a work in progress, at this stage we can report about the outputs. A detailed report about the outcomes can be done once all the outputs are achieved in the upcoming report. 1. 700 female police officers in the female police unit are better able to maintain law and order according to human rights standards and rules of administration of justice. 2. A gender sensitive approach in the work of MoI is mainstreamed through improved safeguards for female police officers 3. Barriers to women reporting crimes are removed 4. Improved international standards and best practice in ensuring equal opportunities for women in the police force II.III project outputs: Output 1.1: Structure of the female police unit developed and meets the needs of the unit and allows officers to properly respond to the security situation across Yemen This output was achieved during the reporting period, under this activity. PRI developed the mandate of the Female Police Academy; as a development of a clear structure of the Female Police Academy in Yemen was achieved, kindly see figure No.2 below which included the Academy vision and mission, institutional values, objectives, organizational structure entailing job descriptions for each post which defines roles and responsibilities, duties that should be delivered by the female officers according to the different locations to which they will be assigned along the line of authorities and management. Also, a manual of procedures and mechanisms was developed for the internal management of the academy A roundtable was organized in Malaysia on February 17 & 18, 2019, that was attended by 17 participants, who represent the top management of the MOI MoI, including the head of the female police unit. the roundtable discussed the role expected from the female police unit and discussed in details, how the unit should be functioning and secured in securing the top political will for the unit, including the full support for the unit from the Human Rights Minister who attended the roundtable and highlighted the value of the unit to secure more protection for the rights of Yemeni women when they come in contact with the law. The Output indictor, identified to measure the progress on this activity was fully achieve ‘Extent to which job descriptions properly define roles and duties of female police officers depending on location, assignment and rank”. Output 1.2: Draft training plan for female police unit adopted by the Yemen Police Academy During the reporting period PRI approached the Dutch police Academy to provide technical support in developing the training plan and be involved in the training process. However, the Dutch police Academy declined the request and informed PRI that by their law they can’t cooperate with NGOs. So, PRI had to look for other options, the Swedish police academy was approached, and PRI never heard an official reply from them. As a result, PRI approached the Jordanian public security department who welcomed cooperation and started working with PRI on developing the training plan and agreed to provide training for the Yemeni female police at the Royal police Academy and female police Academy. ”. As outlined in the training plan. Female police officers will receive a one-month training at the police academy in Jordan that includes field work, as traffic police, at the family protection department and at the investigation crime department. It is anticipated that this training will give all the essential and needed skills for the officers to go back to Yemen able to share and train other fellow colleagues on what they received in Jordan. It should be mentioned that an MoU for cooperation is at the prime minister office in Jordan wating to be signed and approved by the ministerial council. After the signing of the MoU the training will start immediately. Before developing the plan with the police in Jordan and to be able to identify the needs and map the capacity that exists within the team of officers who will be assigned the task of providing the training at the academy in Yemen , PRI organized in Malaysia during October 2019 ,two workshops which mainly discussed the priorities and necessities of the female police in Yemen, and analysed the officers needs and capacities, with the participation of the head of training department at the Jordanian police and the head of the female police force in Jordan. As a result of those workshops the training plan was developed to adapt with the needs of the females police officers with the representation of the senior commanders of the Yemeni Ministry of Interior and the Female Police Unit as well as Jordanian independent expertise. A participatory approach between the direct beneficiaries of the training plan-(Yemeni female police officers) as well as their senior commanders-(Mr. Ali Naser Lakhsha from the MoI and the Head of the Female Police Unit), with the Jordanian expertise-( Director of Police Training Department in Jordan , Women Police Department Head in Jordon)which will be representing the supply side of the delivery of the trainings. This approach adopted for the development of the training plan was an essential method, to ensure a demand based and a structured process during the development of the training plan, as a result this will affect the success during trainings implementation and delivery. The training plan includes two sections: the first is general training courses of all female police officers, which includes all the basic skills in policing as it takes into account the latest trends in international standards adopted in the police sciences. The second is specialized training courses established for the top management of the academy that focus on how to run the academy and deliver their work. The training plan will be covering topics related to policing work standards, management skills, communications skills. Other specialized topics such as Criminal Investigation, community policing, Criminal Intelligence, specialised courses for women police forces. Output1.3: Training courses developed for the Yemen Police Academy PRI started the work to develop the teaching courses for the Police Academy in Yemen to be used by them in delivering the training for the officers. The teaching courses will include: Criminal Law, Patrol Procedures, investigative procedures, Report Writing, Defensive Tactics, Leadership, Ethics, Community Policing, Police, Vehicle Operations, Traffic Enforcement, Accident Investigation, Handling Emotional Situations and First Aid/CPR, GBV investigation, dealing with crimes of human trafficking and crimes of exploitation. These will guarantee the ability of the unit to deliver its work on the ground. Output 1.4: Female officers and trainers at the police academy are trained on and able to deliver a variety of courses dealing with gender specific issues for female recruits via a Training of Trainers (ToT) The TOT workshops were not delivered yet. However; two of the specialized training workshops were implemented in Malaysia in October 2019. Under this output we are providing more information and analysis of the two workshops and the findings that resulted from the assessment of the female officers needs and capacities, their educational level, their level of knowledge of the policing work. That are outlined as follow; The first workshop was organized on October 23rd -25th of 2019 and attended by twenty participants (13 Female & 7 Male) representing the police officers in Yemen. The launching of this workshop was under the patronage of the vice minister of Interior in Yemen and Yemen Ambassador to Malaysia, Jordanian experts and trainers as well as representatives from the Women Police Department and Director of Police Training Department in Jordan, in order to benefit from the Jordanian expertise in strengthening the women police officers capabilities in Yemen. The workshop discussed the priorities and necessities of the Female’s police in Yemen including the following topics: • Women police work ethics • Girls and women in detention (police, prisons and insurance requirements). • Treatment standards for girls and women who come in contact with the law enforcement agencies. • Protection measures for girls and women in detention (treatment of girls and women in prison, and protection requirements). • Alternatives to detention. • The current situation of Women's Police in Yemen challenges and needs. The second workshop was organized in Malaysia between the 27th -29th of October 2019 and attended by twenty participants (13 Female & 7 Male) representing police in Yemen. The launching of this workshop was under the patronage of the vice minister of Interior in Yemen and Yemen Ambassador to Malaysia. The workshop aimed at providing the participants with the knowledge and mechanisms related to empowering and strengthening the role of the female's police work in Yemen and mainstreaming gender aspects. The main topics which were discussed during the three days workshop were: • Mechanisms for dealing with violence cases and abuse against girls and women (domestic violence, protection measures during police procedures). • Mechanisms for enhancing women's police work in Yemen and gender mainstreaming. • The importance of integrating female police officers into the police work (current difficulties and strengthening opportunities). • The use of force in the women police work. • Investigation techniques with women and girls who come in contact with law. • Basics of arresting and inspecting techniques of women in police procedures (the current situation and strengthening opportunities for the purpose of protecting women and girls during the riots procedures and search). The targeted audience chosen for both workshops were police officers who have elementary to mid-level expertise in the policing sector as well as holding higher educational degrees in order to build their capabilities in a series of trainings until we reach a Training of Trainers to equip them with the needed skills of being a trainer. PRI have targeted in the following training, Police officers who are in a junior to mid-level roles mainly clustered around female police officers who have experience between (1-5) years as 56% lies in this category , 6% with (5 to 10) years of experience contributing to 62% of the trainees in the junior-mid level, the minority of the trainees are of senior level. The majority of the trainees hold bachelor’s or Masters Degrees contributing to a total of 95% of the trainees, only 5% of the trainees holds a diploma degree. 65% Trainees Profile Desegregated by Sex 35% PRI have integrated Men and women in the same training for two main purposes: 1) Males colleagues have certain capabilities and skills related to the operations such as arresting and searching techniques which their females colleagues will benefit from. 2) Male colleagues will start to observe the challenges that their females counterparts are facing and what are the barriers that they face in order to be deployed .As a result, the male counterparts attitudes of the non-acceptance of the importance of the female officers will start to shift positively and the male police officers will be the gender champions for their females colleagues. Also, it was observed that 61% of the trainees in both workshops have not been enrolled into the police academy nor graduated from it, only 39% of the total participants have joined the police academy and graduate when the academy was functioning at Sanaa According to the baseline survey distributed in the beginning of the two workshops, it is noticed that around half of the trainees-exactly a percentage of 47 were not enrolled into trainings related for police work before, and this is the first time they were introduced to such trainings, where a 53% have took some trainings before. A Baseline Survey was distributed on the trainees to assess the following dimensions: 1) Workplace Does Workplace Satisfy female police officers’ needs? According to the surveyed sample, the response results were 1:1 ratio of satisfied versus not satisfied of workplace conditions-in other words 50% of the respondents believes that the workplace is not suitable and does not satisfy their needs and the other 50% believes that the workplace does satisfies their needs. 2) Procedures and polices Do you perceive that the current procedures and policies are gender sensitive -? According to the surveyed sample, 1:1 ratio believes that both of the procedures and policies are gender sensitive versus aren’t gender sensitive –in other words 50% of the respondents believe that procedures and policies are not gender sensitive and the other 50% believes that they are gender sensitive. 3) Senior Management Role in Promoting the importance of integrating police females’ officers Phrase Yes No I have full knowledge of international human rights standards. 13% 87% I have the potential to apply international human rights standards. 17% 83% I have full knowledge of the standards of women's policing and gender aspects. 15% 85% I have the potential to apply the standards of women’s policing and gender sensitive aspects 25% 75% Women's police officers play a useful role in promoting gender sensitive treatment 40% 60% I have a full knowledge of the ethics of policing, and the principles for the treatment of women who come in contact with the police. 22% 78% I have the potential to apply policing ethics, and to apply the principles for the treatment of women who come in contact with the police. 44% 56% 63% of the respondents believe that role of senior management is poor or does not exist at all, and 37% believes that the senior management have an effective role. Also, the Baseline assessment survey served as a tool to assess the trainees’ knowledge, those results will be vital to be integrated in the designing and planning phase for developing the training curricula for the Academy. Main findings of the baseline assessment are summarized in the table below-for more details. The results of the baseline assessment ensure the need for the implementation of the current project, which is to strengthen the capabilities of the female police officers through having a female police unit and Academy to deliver a set of specialized trainings.
