A pre and post training assessment was conducted for the trainees in order to assess the degree of change in the level of the learning gain by using different set of questions: Trainees were asked to assess their agreement with a set of concepts and beliefs related to human rights and international standards of treating females who come in contact with the law on a Likert scale The results show an average learning gain equal to (+) 24 % were perceived, the following formula was used to compute the learning gain value: Learning Gain Formula= (Post test Score-Pre-Test Score)/ (Maximum Score-Pre-test Score) Also, a satisfactory survey was distributed to ensure the quality of the service delivered for the trainees which contributes to the success of the training delivery , three main dimensions were assessed as follows: Dimension Training Material and Content Training Facilities- (Venue and Equipment) Trainer Performance 86% 95% 96% Average 92.3% The overall satisfaction rate was computed using the following Equation: Overall Satisfaction Rate= (Weighting Factor * Training Material and Content Satisfaction Score) + (Weighting Factor * Training Facilities Satisfaction Score) + (Weighting Factor *Trainer Performance Satisfaction Score) 0.923 = (0.33*0.86) +(0.33*0.95) +(0.33*0.96) Likert Scale Key-(4 Scale) 1 Very low performance 2 Good performance 3 Very good performance 4 Excellent performance Also, an anecdotal evidence was gathered from the trainees and their senior commander (Head of the female Police Unit) with regards to the following domain of change:  Change in attitudes and confidence of participants The trainees were asked a set of questions to assess the above-mentioned domain of change as follows: 1) To what extent do you feel you are willing and able to be deployed as a member of the female police officers? A sample of the trainees’ responses were as follows: Head of the female Police Unit response 2) To what extent do you feel you have the skills / knowledge to be deployed as a member of the female police officers? A sample of the trainees’ responses were as follows: Head of the female Police Unit response 3) Also, the trainees were asked about their senior commanders’ attitudes towards them in the ability and readiness for deployment as follows: What do your immediate senior commanders feel about you being ready for deployment? The sample taken agreed that their senior commanders are supportive and encourage the female police officers’ deployments. PRI have also asked the female police officers senior commander- (Head of the female Police Unit ) about her feelings; response is as follows: Certainly, managers encourage women police officers, and seeks to enroll them into trainings which will enable the female police officers to be deployed actively in police work and to deliver the work/operations in a better manner. Yet, in return, managers have a crucial role in building the capabilities of their employees through providing the needed support, including support from senior management of the Ministry of Interior, this will contribute to the enhancement of the policewomen performance. 4) Have there been any other developments – positive or negative – as a result of your participation in the trainings delivered in Malaysia? A sample of the trainees’ responses were as follows: They agreed that the workshop delivered by PRI gave the female police officers skills and knowledge which they get for the first time. All of them declared they need more workshops in different topics. Head of the female Police Unit response The positive change brought beyond the training is very clear through the improved performance of police officers in their work facilities. Female police officers became more enthusiastic: We hope that there will be further trainings for the rest of the females working in the women's police. We also wish to expand in the field of exchanging experiences with other countries that have preceded Yemen in the matter of women's police and the nature of its work. This will increase the capacity of female police officers and improve their performance. How does the Trainees Feel with regards to the workshops? Different quotes were gathered from the direct beneficiaries a sample of those quotes are as follows: 1. Output 2.1: Technical support is provided to the police unit to support mainstreaming of gender into the MoI. During the reporting period a gender expert was hired to draft the policy on how gender should be mainstreamed at the MoI work, structure, procedures and services. And she started the process on doing desk research, one to one interview and drafting the policy. However, up till the reporting period the policy was not approved by the MoI yet. However. Several advocacy meetings to promote the policy and gender mainstream within the MoI was organized, including the following; 1. May 2019, Coordination Meeting with the Vice Minister of the Interior to discuss project activities and coordination with the MoI, and the plan to deploy women officers. 2. June 2019 Coordination meeting with the General Director of Training in the MoI and Head of Female Police to discuss the criteria of participants of the ToT Training, their backgrounds, skills and the roles that they will be assigned in managing the academy. 3. June 2019, Meeting with the General Director of Training in the MoI and Head of Female Police to approve the participants list and review applications and approve the structure and the tasks of each trainee. 4. July 2019, Meeting with the Vice Minister of the Interior to discuss rehabilitation of the Female Police Academy to discuss the gender policy and the guidelines for work. The documents were submitted to the minister for approval after their amendment in line with the vice minster comments and feedback. 5. July 2019, Meeting with the General Director of Training in the MoI and Head of Female Police for arranging the workshop” Priorities, necessities and policies of women's police work in Yemen” which targeted 20 participants from the Female police in Yemen. 6. Aug 2019, meeting with the MoI to starting in the technical study of Female Police Academy. Output2.2: Improved infrastructure of the unit and training locations for female police officers During the reporting period the work started on finding a location for the unit and the academy, however, this process was a major challenge for the project due to the conflict. A number of locations were identified, and a committee was organized by the MoI and PRI to assess these locations. However, for security reasons many of these locations were excluded, and the other locations were excluded because they are completely destroyed and need more money for their renovation than what is included in the budget. Based on the committee report, PRI approached the deputy minister of interior to identify other locations that are suitable. PRI team have conducted a mutual meeting with all the MoI, family protection directorate and the women policing department representatives to agree on the required rehabilitation needs and technical constructive aspects. This meeting was held by the management teams of both parties and technical expertise represented by a construction engineer from PRI side and another construction engineer from the Yemeni side, according to this meeting the specifications of the proposal were drafted and PRI issued two procurements as follows: 1) A call for procurement for infrastructure work of the female police academy to be conducted in Aden was released on August 2019 in the official newspaper, the total number of bids received were 10. 2) A call for procurement for the infrastructure work of the female police unit in the MoI to be conducted in Aden was released in July 2019 in the official newspapers, Three bids were received and an internal committee have evaluated the bids. The bid was awarded for a construction company which have started the designing work and provided PRI with a proposed sketch of the renovation work to be done Output 3.1: The role of the unit is promoted, and the public is informed of its mandate and roles During the reporting period noting was achieved under this output, since its linked to achieving the other outputs of the project. Output 4.1 Dissemination of the lessons learnt and good practice from the project at an international level Nothing was achieved under this activity yet.
Section II. Achievements of Project Results and Activities, Nov. 2019 - Apr. 2020:
II.I Overall Goal The project aims at achieving the following goal, enhance peace and security efforts in Yemen through building the capacity of the female police unit at the MOI. During the reporting period this goal was the major massage that was used to promote the establishment of the Women police unit and the academy. In all it correspondence with the Yemeni authorities, PRI stressed on the importance that the female police will play in terms of securing peace and security in Yemen. A goal that was welcomed by the Yemeni MOI who confirmed their willingness to work towards achieving the project goal. The indicators for this goal by their nature can’t be assessed at this stage of the project life, measuring these indicators will be only possible once the female officers are deployed to their duty stations. Noting that at this stage some of the police officers were deployed to work at the prison department and other locations and they received training from PRI as part of this project to enhance their skills and needed knowledge that will enable them to do their jobs as outlined below. Goal indictor NO.1: Percentage of the public reporting feeling safer since the introduction of the female police unit Goal indictor NO.2: Percentage of the public who are satisfied with the work of the female police unit and its contribution towards peace and security efforts. At the end of the project a survey will be conducted in the locations that have female officers to assess the impact and the general public views about their involvement to be able to respond to the success in reaching these indicators II.II Project outcomes: While the outcomes identified by the project, are considered a work in progress, at this stage we can report about the outputs. While a detailed report about the outcomes can be done once all the outputs are achieved. 1. Female police officers in the female police unit are better able to maintain law and order according to human rights standards and rules of administration of justice. 2. A gender sensitive approach in the work of MoI is mainstreamed through improved safeguards for female police officers. 3. Barriers to women reporting crimes are removed. 4. Improved international standards and best practice in ensuring equal opportunities for women in the police force. II.III project outputs: Output 1.1: Structure of the female police unit developed which meets the needs of the unit and allows officers to properly respond to the security situation across Yemen PRI developed the mandate of the female police academy in the first year of the project a clear structure of the female police academy in Yemen was developed, the structure of the academy includes each of the academy’s vision, mission, and institutional values, along the key objectives. Also the academy’s organizational structure was developed, for the purpose of defining the arrangement of interaction between resources, people and tasks within the academy. The organizational structure is represented in the form of a chart, with roles, titles and positions listed in a cascading fashion. In additions to that , job descriptions for each post was developed defining the roles and responsibilities, duties that should be delivered by the female officers according to the different locations to which they will be assigned ,with the responding line of authorities and management. Also, a manual of standards of procedures and mechanisms was developed for the internal management of the academy- to ensure that the female police officers will be able to carry out their jobs ,according to a standardizes mechanisms. Output 1.2: Draft training plan for female police unit adopted by the Yemen Police Academy During the first year of the project PRI approached the Dutch police Academy to provide technical support in developing the training plan and be involved in the training process. However, the Dutch police Academy declined the request and informed PRI that by their law they can’t cooperate with NGOs. So, PRI had to look for other option, were the Swedish police academy was approached and PRI never heard from them. As a result, PRI approached the Jordanian public security directorate who welcomed cooperation and started working with PRI on developing the training plan and agreed to provide training for the Yemeni female police at the Royal police Academy and female police Academy. An MOU was signed to start that training in March. However, due to the COVID and the lockdown in Jordan that training was postponed to take place in October 2020
Output1.3: Training courses developed for the Yemen Police Academy PRI have been working on developing the training courses during the reporting, 11 Training courses were developed during the reporting period, One Basic Introductory course and 10 specialized training courses a brief of the elven training courses developed are listed below, the training materials were in the process of revision by the MOI. Foundational Course for preparing the trainers The foundational course was developed to equip the female police officers with the required set of skills to be able to become trainers and deliver the required set of trainings for the female police officers, as the trainers is expected to deliver a set of trainings in an organized and planned effort to develop the knowledge, experience and attitudes of the trainees by making them more effective in carrying out their tasks. The Foundational Curricula is focusing on equipping the trainer with the needed training dynamic to bring about changes in information, experiences, and attitudes of the trainees in order to enable them to take advantage of their potentials and which helps to raise the efficiency in the practice of their work in a regular manner and high productivity . It is also a continuous process centred on the individuals as a whole that aims to bring about specific mental behaviour changes to meet current or future needs that the individuals require to perform the work need to be done. The trainer is the base of the training and the first pillar of the success of the training process, which means any shortage or deficiency in their knowledge or personal abilities or mental behaviour will negatively affect the result of the training process, Accordingly the basic foundational curricula is of a great asset for having a solid foundation for the personal who are nominated to become trainers. Working on Borders, and Foreigners Affairs Course This course is intended to equip the female police officers with the needed knowledge for dealing with citizens across borders including foreigners affairs regulations, This course It is evident that each state has its own law in regulating the entry, and residence of foreigners on its territory, but it is known that the movement of foreigner’s entry, or exit of any country must be characterized by adequate legal, and administrative regulation to facilitate the movement of people between countries, which means that the states commit to join through treaties and conventions to regulate the movement and residence of foreigners in any country. Therefor in this curse, a presentation of the most important aspects in international agreements governing the security of land, sear, and air borders, and then the general rules for organizing foreigner’s residency before we detail the provisions of Yemen law No. 47 of 1991 regarding entry and residence of foreigner’s for the female police officers. Security Media Course The following course will equip the female police officers with the main content of the role of media, where media plays a vital role in influencing the various fields of life, as security is influenced by the media. The course is designed according to the philosophy of the relationship between the media and Security. In this Course, the trainees will be introduced on how media is based on addressing the feeling, and security is a feeling through which the individual feels safe and reassuring, so addressing this feeling through the media affects profound and rapid impact on security, this effect might be positive for the citizens to feel safe, secure, and give prestige, respect, and appreciation to the security personnel. The opposite would be creating a negative impact which does not serve security but leads to reduce the importance of the security services and showing them without their true appearance, which leads to disturbance and lack of confidence in the ability of the security services to achieve their goals. Therefore, the trainees will introduced to the importance for which the security services in the modern states had to enter into a positive relationship of cooperation and integration with the media in order to serve the human goals for which these agencies are working and to ensure that the media take advantage of information from their original sources from these agencies exaggerations that exceed the fact of events and cause fear and confusion among the society. Community Police Foundational course This course will highlight the importance of balancing between the authority of the police, as police is one of the most prominent manifestation of power in the state, according to the development of the idea of the public authority referred to above as its concept evolved from the idea of the authority of the state, and that the authority is represented for applying the law to a community service to preserve the security of the individual and society in order to achieve its well-being and preserve the rights of public freedoms and the difference is vast and clear between those who believe that it is an authority on society and those who work for society as a servant of their security and stability ,therefore the current course will highlight that police have become in modern international trends providing a security service to the society and in this sense it is not as authority on society which means police individuals will be working for serving the society according to the legalized frameworks within the police agency. Basics of Criminal Investigations Course This course is concerned to introduce the female police officers for what are the standardized best practices for Criminal Investigations ,as investigation is the realization of the truth, and it comes in the sense of searching for the truth, and it could be summarized as “The set of legal procedures that the competent authority undertakes to discover the crime, and collect interferences that established the relationship between the crimes, and its perpetrators, arrest them, and present them to the public prosecution”. In the current course an emphasis on the need of the investigation procedures must be legitimate, and do not violate the law, that is the means of criminal investigation are not inconsistent with the principles of the law, and are difficult to confine to the continuous development, and renew scientific discoveries in this field. Criminal Intelligence Foundation Course In the current course, the female police officers will be introduced for the basics of the criminal Intelligence, as Intelligence training on criminal work needs to build accumulated knowledge, and skills which are foundation rules, and the basic skills that are built on in advanced courses, and will not be inclusive of all the skills, and knowledge of intelligence trainings. It is also necessary to indicate that the training material here is for criminal intelligence only, and it differs greatly from training in intelligence related to state security. Special Operations The special police units evolved in the early sixties, and increased its burdens, and duties to be responsible for combating terrorist acts, local and international organized crime. Special Operations teams are the striking force of major police operations, receive careful and special training, and have as many means, and weapons as they can in order to carry out their duties in the best manner possible, this will be depending on two main domains which are: 1- Force: Mostly in dangerous arrests, hostage release, and/ or VIP protection 2- Speed: Such teams are distinguished by the speed of carrying out the duties assigned to them, as the first pillar of their work is to have the need attributes to deal with surprising events, and this requires Intelligence speedy responses. This course will serve as a foundational course, specialized topics such as advanced courses in marksmanship (especially sniper shooting), the use of explosives, and prevention of what is known in the science of security operations as “fool traps”. Traffic Control Course In this course, the practical importance of the traffic police is the core, as police traffic officers are totally concerned with monitoring, and organizing road traffic, supervising, and achieving traffic safety. It is inconceivable that traffic officers will be law enforcers without training, and know the basics of the law, and traffic safety procedures, and rules. Foundational Drug Control Course In the current course, the female police officers will be introduced on the main definition of drugs, as originally the drugs were unprescribed medications, and due to their psychological, physical, and mental effects, they became very popular, despite its dangerous, and deadly effect, and they are obtained illegally without the medical need for them, and without consulting a doctor, where the drug is called street medicine in some cases. Also, the female officers will be introduced to the effects of the drugs, as the drugs have different, and unexpected effects, which may lead to the suffering of their users from serious health complications, especially among young people, and adolescents. These effects, and complications depend on several different factors, such as the amount, and type of drug used, the number of drugs used at the same time, the health status, weight of the user, and the situation in which the drugs were consumed. Also they will be introduced to the legalized approaches for controlling drugs according to the Yemeni-law along the best international practices as drugs have many types, and are not limited to drugs only as they include other materials that are not used in legal ways such as inhaling paint materials, glue intentionally and in large quantities.
Foundation Principles for Prisons Course The intellectual basics of modern theories in punishment is that the goal of punishment is reform, not punitive. The concept of punishment changed from deterrence, cruelty for inmates to attempting to reform, refine, and re-adapt to their community. The deprivation of liberty as a punishment was a goal itself. For this reason, prisons in the past were a place to achieve this goal, as they were adopted in a way that causes fear, depression, and the convicts were consigned to them without regard to the principles of classifications, as they were treated cruel. In the current course the female prison officers will be introduced for the international standards for dealing with prisoners according to human rights principles. Output 1.4: Female officers and trainers at the police academy are trained on and able to deliver a variety of courses dealing with gender specific issues for female recruits via a Training of Trainers (ToT) A memorandum of understanding (MOU) was signed between Penal Reform Intranational and the Public Security Directorate in Jordan on March 2020, for the purpose of delivering a set of training courses based on the training plan and training courses developed for a group of female police officers from the Republic of Yemen, who will be teaching the other officers at the academy in Yemen. It was supposed that the first training took place immediately after signing the agreement, but due to the COVID-19 the workshop was postponed.
During the process of signing the MOU, PRI were sustaining a continuous communication channels, effort were done over the past months through several consultations with the MOI in Aden, represented by the Deputy Minister, Mr. Lakhsha and the head of female police unit, to agree on the time frame for delivering the remaining activities of the project and the feasibility for delivering them, in light of the ongoing conflict and COVID-19.PRI had a couple of meetings with the head of the female police Unit in Jordan and the Head of training within the Police to discuss the possible time frame to proceed with the training of the Yemeni police at the Royal police academy and the female police training centre in Jordan. That was postponed due to the COVID-19 and the lockdown on travel. It was agreed with the Police department in Jordan, that when the borders are open and the lockdown on travel is left. Two workshops will be organized each one of them is one month for the benefit of the selected group of Yemeni police officers who will manage the training at the police academy in Yemen. The Jordanian authorities pledged to priorities this and start the training immediately considering that the course have been designed and participants have been selected and agreed by the two parties MOI in Yemen and Jordanian police. PRI expect that the time frame for this will be between Mid-August after Eid holiday till Mid October.
With regards to the specialized workshops; and during the reporting period a specialized training workshop for the benefit of the female police officers working at the prisons took place in Amman - Jordan on March 2020; at the aim of the role of female police in prison administration, the importance of gender-responsive treatment . 14 officers working in Yemeni prisons participated in this workshop, the workshop was carried out along three days from the 15th -17th of March 2020
Several aspects were discussed such as women's police duties in prisons as well as guarantees for the protection of female prisoners, hygiene and health care for women prisoners and the role of the police women care for pregnant prisoners, mothers and children accompanying their mothers and girls in prisons. The role of female police in prisons in implementing effective programs for the rehabilitation of women and girls who are imprisoned, including psychological and social rehabilitation programs, as well as programs to prepare for life outside of prison for women prisoners.
Output 2.1: Technical support is provided to the police unit to support mainstreaming of gender into the MoI. The gender expert is working on drafting the policy on how gender should be mainstreamed at the MOI work, structure, procedures and services, the process is entailing a desk research, one to one interview to guarantee a rigorous policy based on the current facts and needs of the sector.
PRI have managed to have a strong relationship with the senior management of both the MOI and the female police unit through organizing different sets of meetings as follows-The total Number of meetings, roundtables with senior management at the MoI and the female police unit to promote gender mainstreaming in the police force during the current reporting period are two meetings as follows: 1) A meeting with the vice president of the ministry of interior was organized on the February 29th , 2020, for the purpose of discussion of the site hand over of the female police academy. 2) A meeting with each of the General Director of projects in the MOI along the General Director of training in the MOI ,and secretary of the vice minister of interior on the first of March 2020 was held for the purpose of the discussion of the developed training courses, and the delivery of the courses methodology for the police officers. Also, during the same meeting a discussion about the infrastructure work was raised, concerning the implementation methodology of the work on the female police academy through the current circumstances of conflicts and an agreement on a six locations to be renovated to meet women needs were identified.
Output 2.2: Improved infrastructure of the unit and training locations for female police officers Output 2.2: Improved infrastructure of the unit and training locations for female police officers Female Police Academy: At the beginning of the reporting period, the decision of choosing the contractor to work on the renovation of female police academy was taken by a committee of representatives from the MOI, Female Police Unite and PRI; however due to the conflict in Yemen the site handover delayed until the 19th of March 2020. (Please see annex No. 1) Since November 2019, PRI conducted a mutual meeting with all of the MOI, family protection directorate and the women policing department representatives to agree on the required rehabilitation needs and technical constructive aspects, and kept following up with the MOI to handover the site, the approval form the MOI to start the work on the renovation sent on the 24th of February; Two follow up meetings were conducted to discuss the handover the site of the female police academy, the first meeting was on the 29th of February 2020 with the vice Minister of Interior , the second meeting was conducted on 1st of March 2020, with the purpose of the discussion of the implementation methodology of the renovation work in the academy, this meeting was held with each of the director of together foundation in Yemen and the director of planning, general director of projects and general director of training and secretary of the vice Minister of Interior, affiliated for the police directorate in Yemen.
Accordingly, on March 19th, 2020, a hand over of the site for the purposes of construction, and renovation of the female police academy in (ADAN, KHOUR-MKASAR / ALNASIR) has delivered, and the work started and accomplished 50% of its infrastructure till 22nd of April; (please see attached annex No.2 - the report)
Challenges encountered during the implementation of the renovation and rehabilitation work of the female police academy - The most important challenges that met the work of the academy is the political tension in Aden in addition to the destruction of most buildings and organs of the Ministry of Interior in Aden, where no building or suitable site for the project was found until August 2019 and after the identification of the current location in August 2019 there were military confrontations between the legitimate government forces in Aden and the forces of the Transitional Council and therefore PRI were not able to start working until March 2020. - the cost of the reinvention got higher than we expected due to the raise of the prices of the row materials, and the severe damage that was caused for the selected building by the conflict, and the security cost that the contractor had to pay to secure his equipment - After the completion of 50% of the renovation work and after the date of April 22, 2020 the city of Aden swept large torrents and rain and did not affect the academy site being far from the torrential streams, but the rains made the contractor stop working temporarily and then got the new tension resulting from the political conflict and announced the Transitional Council on April 25 autonomy for Aden and the southern provinces as the outbreak began. In addition to the fact of work in Ramadan, which resulted in a fewer working hours, where many construction workers prefer not to work during Ramadan, where the contractor have submitted an official letter requesting to postpone the renovation, and rehabilitation of the female police academy in Aden. - Due to COVID-19 the work on renovating the academy was stopped.
On the other hand; during the meeting on the 1st of March; also discussed the identification of six locations to be renovated to meet women needs to be friendly for the female police officers; The six locations have been agreed with MOI, including points at the borders, the port, largest police
Output 3.1: The role of the unit is promoted, and the public is informed of its mandate and roles The promotion of the role of the department, some of the promotional materials were developed and sent to MOI for approval before their distribution, the documentary will start after finishing the work on the academy and the six locations, however, some filming started to document the work on the infrastructure and will be ready in both English and Arabic before the end of the project.
Output 4.1 Dissemination of the lessons learnt and good practice from the project at an international level The dissemination of the lessons learnt and good practice from the project at an international level was intended to be delivered through an international advocacy, unfortunately two major global events in which the Yemeni experience of the project was supposed to be presented and Yemeni MOI was supposed to participate were postponed due to COVID-19, the crime commission in Vienna, were a side event was supposed to be organized to talk about role of Yemeni female police during conflict and their contribution to building peace and security in Yemen, and the crime congress in Japan, were a side event were supposed to be organized to discuss the establishment of Yemeni female police department and its impact of peace and security. The two events were postponed till 2021. However, from here till the end of the project the following international advocacy events will take place; a side event in Geneva in Sept during the human rights council meeting, a side event in New York during the security council meeting, and a policy paper that highlights the role of the female police in Yemen in building peace and security will be issued.

Project final beneficiaries: The final beneficiaries of the project are: society at large in Yemen, with a focus on vulnerable groups including women, children, marginalized groups. Direct beneficiaries: are MOI, 700 female police officers that were hired in the South, the Police Academy.

Risk Assessment Nov. 2018 - October 2019: 1) Political instability in Yemen Aggravated political instability leading to violent armed conflict, causing lack of security and threat to lives will have high impact on the project. Activities will have to be postponed or moved to secure areas, setting new priority locations depending on developments on the ground, and the potential effect of armed conflicts on the future of the geographic location. Political instability resulting in changing of governmental bodies, laws and regulations but not affecting people’s safety and security will have medium impact on the project. However, such changes might have short-term negative effects and cause delays in delivering the project activities. On the other hand, they may create a favourable environment to advocate for overall justice reforms and the promotion of human rights for the long term, when new laws and regulations are in development. A regular risk assessment done by MENA regional office on a monthly basis according to consultation between the project team based in Yemen with MoI. PRI will tolerate low-medium range of risks inherent in field work, and in districts where high risk is associated with field work, relevant activities will be moved to safe areas, as a way to mitigate the risk, and make sure that the project goal and objectives are not jeopardized by temporary developments on the ground. One of the key examples, is shifting the location of the police academy into a safer place will be taken as a mitigation action by PRI management in order to be able to implement the project activities. PRI mitigation response were taken as a result of the continuous engagement and consultation done between PRI and the MoI . Where the MoI informed PRI to wait till April 2020, and promised to solve the issue which hindered to have the academy in Aden. Otherwise, a new building that is in Hadhramaut might be chosen. Regional offices have the experience and expertise in many geographic areas in the MENA region, Asia, Africa, central Europe, to determine when work is safe to be carried out and will adapt their work accordingly to achieve the sought-for results. Additionally, PRI will work through local staff who are well trained and neutral, and not targeted, with a low risk to their safety and security. In relation to regional and international experts, PRI will use all safety procedures followed by the UN, including staying in safe hotels and avoiding high risk areas; additionally, the MoI is willing to provide security and guards for the experts if needed. 2) Access to professional development for women police officers: A barrier to the career advancement of women in policing may take the form of inequitable access to training courses, due to the unavailability of the needed facilities and expertise to deliver the needed courses for the females, and eventually to promotion in their career. A male dominated work may affect the equal opportunities offered to women. In addition police employees, including women, living in remote and rural communities have less opportunities, especially if the course involves an extended residential component. women with both family and career responsibilities may be less inclined to apply for training. PRI’s project objective is to provide the right for women to join the police forces and receive adequate training for a range of different work responsibilities. PRI will also work on deploying the women in different field areas. However, as part of the sustainability of the project goal and objectives, through regular meetings with the senior officials of the MoI , PRI will build a curricula that will require involving the women police in the future training and academic course . The training by PRI will empower women to become a significant number and an asset in the police units. PRI will also provide best practices related to equal training opportunities for women in distant areas from the center. 3) The led coalition unwillingness to cooperate and setting obstacles in the deployment of female police in the different areas controlled by their forces. This risk is considered Medium in Yemen, as one of the major impacts of Arabic coalition support to the International Recognized Government (IRG) was a control on the buildings of the official ministries and their movements, yet PRI developed the project proposal in consultation with their allies in the MoI and got approval from the Deputy Minister of Interior on the project activities. PRI signed an MOU with the MoI before starting the implementation. Over the last 6 years PRI has built strong working relations with the Ministry of Interior in Yemen, through working with them on juvenile justice and prison reform. PRI ensures a continues coordination with the senior management of the MoI and the women police and use its good relations with senior officials and decision makers, in addition to its previous cooperation with many ministries of the coalition countries, six coordination meetings were conducted between PRI and the senior management of both the MoI and women police to facilitate the organisation of activities , and the deployment of trained female police, in addition to facilitate their daily duties , and mandate. 4) Lack of social support The lack of social support can be another barrier for women to succeed in their duties in the field. A police woman required to intervene at the different levels of the justice sector might face the strain and the effects of environmental or external barriers. women trained might not sustain their jobs. PRI previous experiences in the justice sector in Yemen, including at high managerial institutional level , showed a high social support for women equal participation. Historically Yemen, was leading in women participation as judges, and even as police officers. Prior to the conflict two thousand women officers were part of the police units, the armed conflict and the humanitarian situation forced them to leave (only sixty stayed). A societal angel of the Yemeni Context including-(Female police officer family members , or husband), women is not accepted to work in certain fields such as the security field especially in operational roles, where there is a stereotyping for her role based on being a female. This will have a burden on females. Females needs to challenge the society were she is working in and to proof her ability for such roles in security sector and operational roles in specific. The project will build on previous successes, and social support to re-introduce the female element to police, empowered by professional training. PRI will also conduct advocacy campaigns with senior opinion leaders in the society, and will build the capacity of the media outlets to gain support of the different components of the society, including a follow up by media to the efficient interventions of women police in fields of women justice , and children in conflict with the law. Any negative strains will be tackled and criticised by the media, and partners from opinion leaders

It was supposed that the project ends on the 31st of October 2020
The project started on the 1st of November 2018

Enhancing law enforcement response to COVID-19 in Jordan

description.narrative:
I. Annual Progress : In May 2020, a contract was signed between the embassy of the kingdom of the Netherlands in Jordan and Penal Reform International to implement a project titled “Enhancing law enforcement response to COVID-19 in Jordan". The project worked during its six months period on promoting safe access to justice during the pandemic, including individuals who come in contact with the law enforcement and police officers, inmates, juveniles, children accompanying their mothers in jails. The project has succeeded in protecting the rights of individuals who come in contact with the law, either because they committed a crime or because they want to report a crime, or had the need to visit police stations, or courts or other judicial institutions for any reason. The project targeted all the police stations, including the pre-trail hosting cells, as those cells are small, don’t have proper ventilation, and in most cases are overcrowded, and lack hygiene, in addition to the 13 Juvenile police stations. Police officers who interact daily with the individuals who come in contact with the law were targeted to reduce the risk of being infected, and transferring the infection to their families. The same apply to the community police who was in need to interact with the community, responding to the Jordanian community needs during the lock down. Penal Reform International during the project has adopted a customized strategy to respond to the special needs of each category within the security system including the psychological, and physical needs, especially the most vulnerable segment of women, children accompanying their moms in prisons, juveniles. The project was able to provide a better health and justice solutions throughout the community. All which has resulted in a better functioning of the rule of the law system, and enhance the trust of individuals, and citizens in the police measures of maintaining health and safety. The project direct beneficiaries are: The Public Security Directorate officers, including Juvenile police department, community police, individuals who comes in contact with the law and visit police stations, juveniles and children who comes with contact with the law and visit Juvenile police stations, male and female prisoners and children accompanying their mothers. Covid-19 pandemic has globally affected all countries and sectors since November 2019, Jordan and the security sector is part of this global pandemic, all the population which is in a direct interaction with the system-(The Public Security Directorate officers, including Juvenile police department, community police, individuals who come in contact with the law and visit the police stations, in addition to juveniles and children who visit Juvenile police stations, and male and female prisoners and children accompanying their mothers, were at risk of being infected by the virus. In Jordan there are 111 police station scattered across over the kingdom with an average of 84,000 visitors per month, also 17 prison institutions, with a total capacity of 13,352, and hold around 18,000 prisoners up till 20th of March 2020. The prisons were overcrowded, and the project activities came to support the national efforts, including supporting the initiative of the Judicial Council to take a decision of reducing overcrowding in prisons as an urgent response to reduce the rate of incarcerated personnel per prison to reduce the rate of spread of infections among inmates, and prison staff., the project also supported the prison department initiative to protect inmates and build an independence vis a vis the response to the pandemic , and create a production chain of safety gates. On 24th of March 2020 the Judicial Council took a decision of an immediate release for all prisoners with a judgment less than 2 years and replacing the imprisonment with a ban on travel, including drug offenders. In addition to decision of not detaining any financial related crimes that amounts to less than (140,000 USD), replacing that with a ban on travel, and released all prisoners that fall under the same category of crime from prisons with a ban on travel.
As a result, for these measures around 6000 prisoners were released from prisons to reduce the prison population from 18,000 to 12,642 prisoners according to official statistics of Correctional and Rehabilitation Centers (CRCs) on the 6th of April 2020. Additionally, CRCs took a set of preventive measures inside the prisons that included allocating one prison only for new prisoners who will be detained all over Jordan (Al-Balqa prison). In an attempt to reduce the risk of infection spread which might be coming with new prisoners coming from outside the prisons. So, no new prisoners will be entering any of the prisons facilities that already had prisoners before, until they are quarantined for some time in Al-Balqa prison first. This will enable the CRCs to reduce the risk of infection spread that might come from outside the prisons, and maintain the health of inmates, prison staff, and their families at homes.

IV. Risks and bottlenecks Risks related to context: Governmental well and priorities: PRI has ensured continuous communication channels with the PSD high officials which enabled a smooth implementation of the project activities utilizing mutual efforts and resources, accordingly all the interventions were implemented in agreement with the PSD priorities and the governmental regulations related to the defence orders. Risks related to programming: Lack of social acceptance for behavioural change and responding for the health preventive measures by the prisoners or their relatives: PRI have designed the awareness campaigns and advocacy activities with relevance to the targeted audience needs and comprehension levels of the main preventatives measures regarding COVID-19, accordingly the awareness posters were designed with a very simple language along illustrative symbols of the actions to be taken. Also, women and children were not excluded as the design of the posters was gender sensitive, along a special design made for the children. Risks related to the organization: Anti-fraud and anti-corruption policy within the organization: PRI has adopted its’ bribery and an anti-corruption policy, including its’ various financial procedures and controls, during the implementation of the project activities, PRI has used its’ legal ways of providing financing to the partners in Jordan. Along to, ensuring the on-going monitoring mechanism, of resources and expenditures via budget financial controls. Organization structure and culture: Penal Reform International is an international non-governmental organization working on penal and criminal justice reform worldwide. PRI has regional offices and programmers in the Middle East and North Africa, Central and Eastern Europe, Central Asia and the South Caucasus. Also, PRI work with partner organizations in other parts of Africa and, using a variety of approaches, on penal reform issues in Asia, North and Latin America and the Caribbean. PRI has Consultative Status with the United Nations (ECOSOC) and the Council of Europe, and Observer Status with the African Committee on the Right and Welfare of the Child, the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights, and the Inter-Parliamentary Union. PRI is also a registered civil society organization with the Organization of American States (OAS).PRI works with governments, and civil society to improve conditions of detention. PRI promotes greater transparency and accountability in the criminal justice and penal systems through holistic policy development and legal reform, including encouraging reform processes aimed at humanising juvenile justice, detention conditions and implementing rehabilitation programmes, the development and implementation of international human rights instruments in relation to law enforcement and prison conditions, the elimination of unfair and unethical discrimination in all penal measures. PRI’s work involves cooperation and collaboration with governments, other official authorities and non-governmental partners, which helps PRI, maintains impartiality, sustainability and builds trust with all of its partners. PRI covers the Middle East and North Africa region from its Jordan office. It has been working in this region for 14 years now, covering 13 countries.
Monitoring, evaluation and management quality: PRI has developed a project monitoring, evaluation and learning (MEL) system to track the results of the project. The MEL system has included: A theory of change which shows the logical linkages and assumptions between the goal, results, outputs and activities. A monitoring framework with results statements, milestones, targets and identified data collection sources. The project team have systematically collect data to track the indicators at outcome and output level utilizing various data collection tools and reporting templates.
Financial and administrative management: As an international NGO with 30 years of history, PRI has well-established financial management mechanisms for its programmatic activity. In the first instance, a day-to-day financial administration for the project has be undertaken by the MENA finance manager, with the oversight of the Project Manager. The MENA finance manager has reported on a monthly basis to the Regional Director and Financial Director in London, who oversees the whole financial transactions of the MENA office. Monthly reports on the financial performance of the project has been submitted to PRI home office. These are checked against financial projections which are agreed between the London and Regional Offices at the commencement of any programme. Major changes to the spending of the project are discussed between the Financial Managers and the Regional Director.
V. Sustainability:
Self-sufficiency approach and positive investment in the prisoners was utilized during the phases of the current project, which guarantees sustainability, as the relation between PRI, the PSD and CRC is not supplier to consumer relationship rather a supplier to supplier relationship, which means that PRI is not acting as a direct provider of technical services and logistical support for a final consumer institution, but rather for an institution which will act as a supplier of new products. And this is guaranteed, through the vocational and reintegration programs prompted inside the prisons. From that time onward ,the prisoners started manufacturing the needed Sterilization Machines, to be used for preventing the spread of COVID-19 in all the police stations and juvenile police department and CRCs all across Jordan.
Visibility PRI has worked during the implementation of the project on guaranteeing the visibility of the donor, through continuous communication and coordination between the project manager and the embassy staff prior publishing or printing or distributing any materials to the public, either in a tangible and/or electronic format, and ensuring a proper branding for the kingdom of Netherlands logo per the instructions and regulations embedded by the embassy. This has covered the publications produced during the project timeline-(ex. The health protocol, Awareness Posters), and the digital outreach (ex. PRI official Facebook page, local News channels, Radio Broadcasting), as well as the advocacy activities through the documentary produced in partnership with the PSD aiming at communicating the shared results and illustrating the impact of the contributions. In addition, all tangible aids provided for the PSD and CRCs were properly branded with the logo of the embassy including the sanitation gates, face masks and gloves packages, gender sensitive products packages, sanitizing products packages, COVID-19 medical apron packages.

The project was implemented within the planned timeline, based on MoU’s and field inspection and follow up. PRI provided a rapid support for the Public Security Directorate and the Correctional and Rehabilitation Centers including Women Correctional and Rehabilitation Centers, along with the Juvenile police department to response to COVID -19 pandemic. The project was able to achieve the following outcomes and outputs as follows:
Outcome No. 1: New behavioral and attitudinal practices adopted within the security system (represented mainly within the CRC and PSD, juvenile’s department boundaries) for responding to the COVID-19. PRI has developed a guideline which was adopted by the PSD, and the CRCs, including preventive measures in line with the WHO standards, to ensure safety of the police staff, individuals who come in contact with the law and the community in general. The PSD took new measures to respond to COVID-19 that were discussed in different meetings with PRI which included: • Family visits suspended in order to reduce the dangers of the contact with the contaminated outside world. • Virtual courts, which allowed an online adjudication of cases. • Immediate release of inmates with cases adjudicated up to two years, replacing it with a ban on travel, as an effort to end overcrowding. • Appointing Al-Balqa prison to be the only prison for admitting new prisoners, keeping them for a minimum of two weeks, to ensure that they are negative COVID-19 cases prior transferring them into other prisons across the kingdom.
Outcome No. 2: Self-sufficiency approach through positively involving the prisoners adopted within the security system for securing the logistical and supply needs in emerging crisis. The following outcome was achieved through utilizing the principle of give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime’, involving the prisoners in manufacturing sanitization gates at Al-Swaqa prison, then distributing them at all main entrances of police stations, juveniles police departments and CRCs reaching 94.3% of self-sufficiency of those gates for the security sector as a whole. The experience of involving the inmates in the production process of the sanitation gates has raised their confidence level, as they contributed in the national efforts towards combating the pandemic. As the total number of police stations (111), juvenile police centers (13), and prisons (17) all across Jordan equaling 141., Producing 133 sanitation entrance gates, contributed to 94% of the total PSD needs. Outcome No. 3: Trust is enhanced, and made stronger due to the measures taken by the PSD to sustain access to safe justice and protect right to health and reach out to the community through community policing with positive messages, raising awareness of the public, and defending the public right to health. The Trust between the Jordanian society and the PSD has been enhanced, as a result of a set of activities delivered by PRI jointly with PSD which was promoted through national TV and social media platforms, radio broadcasting .The trust gained by the Jordanian citizens can be demonstrated in two main proxy indicators: -The number of people that accessed the police stations has increased, or was not affected by the pandemic, in comparison with the same period of the previous year, which shows that the Jordanian community has the trust to go to the police stations when they need to get a service or have to report for a crime to those centres. In the first three months of the lockdown and the domestic abuse crime rate increased by 33%, compared to the same time the year before. The stress level increased with a 1685 new domestic abuse cases made in the first three months of the lockdown including physical, sexual, and physiological abuses which caused the reported cases to increase at the police stations. .The citizens felt safe reporting their complains to the nearest police station to their homes, as they trust the justice system, and the PSD in protecting their right.
In addition, the evaluation done with the direct beneficiaries from the One-Body initiative, shows the enhancement of the trust as the following statistics prove:
According to a survey done with the direct beneficiaries of the 141 food parcels, 130 (92%) went to the police station to collect the parcels. Nine (6%) had the parcel delivered to their houses. 2% did not respond to the question. Of the 130 that went to the police station, seven had already been to the station before. 123 (95%) had never been to the police station before (36 or 29% Jordanians; 87 or 71% Syrians). One respondent specifically mentioned that due to living with physical handicap they were not able to go to the police station to collect the parcel, and therefore had it delivered.
Almost all (97%) of the respondents reported feeling "completely safe" when receiving the food parcel. 93% were "completely satisfied" with the distribution process. The 6% who were not satisfied did not provide a reason, although there were some remarks regarding the lack of shade at the distribution site or disorganised distributions at first stages. When asked "Has your perception of the police been impacted?" 94% reported it had for the better, 6% reported no change and 1% for the worse.
Outputs: Output 1.1: PRI managed to develop an educational campaign through creating awareness posters which promotes in easy language with photos the protective and preventive measures that should be taken and followed by the staff and the individuals who visited the police stations . 2000 posters were designed, printed out and distributed among all police stations including the Juvenile departments across the Kingdom. 1400 posters were created targeting adults, and 600 child friendly poster taking into consideration a gender sensitive language in the design of the poster’s instructions and precautions measures (See Annex. No. 1 & 2)
Output 1.2: PRI in cooperation with the public security directorate developed a practical guideline on the response to COVID-19 at the police station’s level, based on the International Standards for Human Rights, WHO, OHCHR health instructions, and Child Rights Committee (CRC) and in line with the Jordanian laws and regulations. .. This guideline serves as a directive tool for the daily procedures that should be undertaken by the police station officers, including topics related to how to mitigate the potential risks resulting from COVID-19 to staff and individuals who come in contact with the law, in addition to preventative measures when dealing with COVID-19, starting at the external gates of the institutions. (See Annex No. 3)
Output 2.1: During the project lifetime PRI supported the PSD in creating a vocational training production line to produce the sanitation gates inside AL-Swaqa prison. PRI coordinated with PSD the production of the sanitation gates inside the prison involving the inmates as part of supporting their rehabilitation, part of the national efforts taken by the government to fight COVID-19.
A capacity building workshop on the vocational programme for the benefit of 45 prisoners was organised at the beginning of the project aiming at teaching the prisoners how to produce the gates. 133 sanitation entrance gates produced and used at the entrance of 111 police station, 13 juvenile police stations, and prisons in Jordan including the female prisons. To make sure that the workshop is sanitized properly and there is no risk for COVID-19 infection PRI provided the safety equipment for everyone involved, including special masks, safety gears, gloves that the prisoners will be wearing during the production phases of the gates
Output 2.2: To make sure that individuals who come in contact with the law have the minima level of protection when they enter stations, and that police officers have the same level of protection and don’t fear the risk of spreading the infection to their families while they are on duty, PRI provided Hygienic supplies for the PSD including 175,800 disposable pairs of gloves, 46,000 reusable face masks, and 487,450 surgical face masks for the benefit of 13,320 officers working at 111 police stations, in addition to 420 officers working with Juveniles at 13 police stations and over 300,000 individuals who visited the police stations during the life of project. In addition PRI run a sanitation campaign inside all police stations in Jordan, and juvenile police stations, including at the pre-trial stage cells, which the detainees stay in during the investigation phases. The launch took place in September with the participation of the representative of the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherland. (See Annex No. 4)
Output 2.3: PRI launched the project in May 2020 in the presence of her excellency the ambassador of Netherlands in Jordan who provided 450 women prisoners with hygienic materials in order to respond to their specific needs and protect their rights to health. 400 pack of antibacterial wipes, 6750 pack of pads and 3270 soap bars were distributed. (See Annex No. 5)
Output 3.1: PRI partnered with Siren to ensure that the role of Community police will still be active during the lockdown across the country. PRI provided Siren with 100,000 disposable sanitized gloves and 10,000 reusable face mask which were distributed to the community police to guarantee that the safety measures are maintained during the distribution of food parcels for families who are in need in North Amman within the One Body Community Initiative, Shoulder to Shoulder Project implemented by Siren.
Output 3.2: PRI in collaboration with the PSD produced a five minutes documentary showing the main measures, and practices made by the Public Security Directorate PSD and the Correctional, & Rehabilitation Centers CRCs, in responding to COVID-19 and the main lessons learnt during the process. The broadcast was published among different media channels, official TV, and social media platforms as part of the project promotion, which in return increased the trust of the Jordanian community of the PSD measures taken to sustain access to justice and protect individual’s right to health. This guaranteed the visibility of the Dutch government contribution, and support to Jordanian population in fighting COVID-19. (See Annex No. 6)
Output 3.3: PRI organized a session with key personnel from the public security directorate, and some prisoners and other representatives of international NGOs, and prison directorate, during which, the main project outcomes were presented including the main measures taken to respond for COVID-19 in Jordan within the security eco-system, and how those measures have contributed to enhancing access to justice and law enforcement rule in protecting the right to health during quarantine.

title.narrative: Building a Compassionate Community in Bangladesh Working Towards Universal Health Coverage

description.narrative: This project will improve access to essential, quality healthcare services for women, men, girls and boys affected by serious chronic and life-limiting conditions in Bangladesh. We will develop an innovative home-based palliative care srevice to improve the quality of life of the poorest, with a focus on women and girls, to progress towards Universal Health Coverage. The project will reach over 2500 people and wil provide an innovative community-based service, which strengthens the health system and provides a model for adaptation throughut Bangladesh, and beyond.

description.narrative: The overarching objective of the NHSP3 programme is to improve the health of women, children, the poor and socially excluded in Nepal, including by restoring health services in areas affected by the 2015 earthquake, and improving the quality and governance of health services nationwide. MEOR is an oversight component of NHSP3. Its primary role is to facilitate continuous adaptation and improvement of NHSP3 to ensure that intended outcomes and impact are achieved.

mailing-address.narrative: Abt Associates, 24 Eversholt Street, London, UK, NW1 1AD

sector.narrative: MEOR is an oversight component of Nepal Health Sector Programme 3 (NHSP3) which is funded by the UK Department for International Development (DFID). Its primary role is to facilitate continuous adaptation and improvement of NHSP3 to ensure that intended outcomes and impacts are achieved. MEOR does this through validation of methods and results monitoring, review and evaluation, research and analysis and knowledge management and learning.

title.narrative: DEC COVID: Immediate humanitarian assistance to most affected and vulnerable children, adolescent boys and girls and their caregivers in Ukhiya Upazila

description.narrative:
This project will remain consistent with Plan International’s global mission to emphasize the needs of women and girls. This project will primarily focus on the host community needs and will be complementary to the existing projects in the camp.
• To address child protection concerns, especially for girls and adolescent women Community Based Child Protection (CBCP) committee members, with the support of community volunteers and mentors, will conduct orientation for child and youth safe space management, training on protective and gender-responsive psychosocial support Child protection, Psychological First Aid (PFA), gender equality, SGBV, SRHR for volunteers, PSHEA and Safeguarding and refresher training on safeguarding to 1200 adolescent boys and girls. • Provide age appropriate and gender responsive support for the 1200 children and adolescents (5-9 year, 10-13 year and 14-17 year). • To reduce the further risk of infection and better prepare the community to be able to move around more safely this project will distribute reusable safety face masks to 55,000 beneficiaries in Camp 1E and in two host communities unions Raja Palong and Palong Khali. • Distribute 600 hygiene kits to 200 adolescent girls and boys in Raja Palong and 400 girls and boys in Palong Khali in Ukhiya sub-district. • Provide 448 host community households with unconditional cash transfers (Minimum Emergency Basket grant) for two months. • COVID-19 awareness messaging including adhesive stickers and poster

Closing Gaps: Strengthening Urban Resilience through Protection and Inclusion Strategies in the Caribbean

description.narrative:
This proposal is aimed at strengthening the capacities of bi-national DRR National Prevention, Mitigation and Response bodies in Cuba and Dominican Republic to permanently learn and collaborate, and to engage in advocacy work towards DRR regional bodies. A series of gaps were identified in the needs assessment, including the lack of institutionalization of key risk management tools and processes, information management during all the phases of the disaster, and coordination between the local, national, bi-national and regional levels. With this in mind, an intervention has been designed that is geared at consolidating local risk management capacities in the municipalities of Baracoa and San Antonio del Sur in Cuba, the institutionalization of tools in the National Prevention, Mitigation and Response Systems in the Dominican Republic and Cuba as well as the establishment of coordination mechanisms between both countries, the development of strategic alliances with CDEMA and CEPREDENAC and advocacy in regional consensus-building spaces. The proposed work will be closely coordinated with other risk management and development initiatives and will strive to develop sustainable risk management agendas in both countries. Direct beneficiaries: 11607 individuals and 82 organizations
Since March 2020 has pivoted and modified for COVID-19 response.

title.narrative: Providing protective, inclusive, safe and continued quality education for Covid-19 and conflict affected children in NE Nigeria
Provision of life saving assistance to children under five years of age suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) amid the COVID-19 Pandemic in Borno and Yobe state, North east Nigeria

description.narrative: Plan International Nigeria will implement a 12-month project focusing on improving access and coverage of quality lifesaving nutrition services integrated with psychosocial support in Borno and Yobe states. The project will also strengthen the capacity of government healthcare providers in Stabilization Centers (SC) ensuring the continuity and sustainability of these vital services amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The project will treat Complicated SAM cases in SCs with formula milk (F100 & F75), daily assess and follow up on the medical condition of the children and take their anthropometric measurement. The project will further provide stimulation, psychosocial support and counselling services, and promote Optimal IYCF-E (Infant and Young Child Feeding in Emergencies) practices. We will support nutrition partners implementing in the community through active case finding/screening, identifying SAM with medical complication at Out Patient therapeutic Program (OTP) centres & refer treated Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) cases from SC to OTP and vis-versa in Kaga, Konduga, Mafa, Hawul, and Chibok Local Government Areas (LGAs) in Borno state and Bade LGA of Yobe state. The proposed project will reach a total of 2501 children (1276 girls &1225 boys) under five-years of age in 6 (six) decentralized SCs in Borno and Yobe state. The proposed activities will strengthen the management of acute malnutrition in Borno and Yobe state by providing inpatient management of SAM in hospitals (SC sites) and also will establish new SC and strengthening the existing SC to provide service for IDP/host communities. In the course of its implementation, the project shall integrate gender responsive messaging in its community engagement processes, share information, encourage discussions and address gender issues that impact optimal IYCF. Given that prevailing gender roles often discourage men from participating in traditionally perceived care roles, the project shall implement a male engagement strategy that will improve male participation and support in positive IYCF practices at household and community levels. In addition, the project will raise awareness on COVID-19 mode of transmission and gender responsive and inclusive prevention strategies. The project will also provide technical and logistical support and strengthen the supportive supervision and monitoring system in the LGAs. The project will focus on supporting the most vulnerable population groups, specifically children under five years of age, caretakers of SAM children, caretakers of SAM children who are living with disabilities and other vulnerable groups. Plan International will integrate management of complicated SAM cases into existing health services in each general hospital and in the LGA health system using State Primary Health Care and Development Agency (SPHCDA) and hospital staff in all targeted LGAs. At project start-up, Plan International Nigeria will prioritize identifying Complicated SAM cases to facilitate access to life-saving services for children under five years of age and to enable management of these SAM cases in collaboration with SPHCDA and hospital board Management staff. We will strengthen the capacity of the government service providers as well as parents, guardians and care takers to prevent malnutrition and respond to the treatment of complicated SAM cases and we will work closely with government and partners working in each LGA. The project will strengthen accountability to beneficiaries through the establishment and strengthening of an inclusive and appropriate community and facility -based complaints and feedback mechanism that will allow women, girls, men, and boys to safely report concerns of the emergency nutrition response in their respective Hospital. The project also will ensure gender sensitive monitoring and evaluation is undertaken by disaggregating all data by sex, age, disability and creating complimentary qualitative and quantitative indicators.

title.narrative: NERF: Resilience Plus

description.narrative:
The “Resilience Plus” programme led by consortium partners Mercy Corps and Plan International aims to reach approximately 2660 people (5330 HHs) across Provinces 1, 2, 5 and 7. The goal of the programme is to ensure COVID-19-related resilience of vulnerable households is strengthened through the value voucher distribution and integrated access to improve to protection services and linkages to safety nets.
Issues of protection and inclusion will be mainstreamed through the project, it includes key activities under Objective 2. Consortium teams will be trained on protection, inclusion, and safeguarding, with consortium members responsible for flowing down this content to local partners. The programme will also engage with the government at multiple levels to advocate for protection and inclusion issues. This will include supporting the local government to activate and implement the protection coordination mechanism. The programme will undertake service mapping and awareness-raising of available services, to ensure people at risk of protection issues have access to preventive and response services for issues like SGBV, and providing emergency referral services for those vulnerable to, or survivors of, VAWG, including SGBV.
Gender is a central compounding disadvantage, so the program will mainstream gender through the project and strive to incorporate gender minimum standards, and incorporate analysis on gender dynamics and decision making at the household level during the needs assessment and PDM, to ensure the programme is gender sensitive. The consortium will ensure attention to gender issues in HR, recruitment, and consortium staff orientation will be a priority. The consortium’s Steering Committee will regularly review gender and inclusion disaggregated data, to ensure responsive programming.
